loans.name: Damarys Group

texts.es:
Damarys is the name chosen by the members of this association because this word includes the word "lady" in their slogan. These women have all the intentions to move on in life with their families.

There are 18 members, they've been around for just 1 year in the Centro Focal de Villa Adela community. Among the many things they do, they purchase and sell local fabric-created arts/crafts such as blankets, skirts, dresses, hats, and even shoes! They sell them in their own stands and others around fairs, hoping to get buyers that way.

This association needs the money in order to improve the quality of their products, taking into consideration the raw material that they are going to use. Sometimes the materials they use do not meet quality standards needed in order to compete with other local vendors. They want to get a steady income in order to support their family and pay their bills.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Damarys es el nombre que escogieron las socias de esta asociación, haciendo referencia a las Damas que componen la misma, mujeres que tienen la intención de salir adelante por ella y por sus familias. Son 18 integrantes, con una antigüedad de apenas un año dentro del Centro Focal de Villa Adela, y dentro de sus muchas actividades a las que se dedican estas socias, se encuentra la compra y venta de artesanías en tela, confeccionan todo tipo de prendas de vestir para señoras de pollera, sombreros, mantas, mantillas y hasta calzados, que venden en algunos casos en puestos propios, otras se dedican a deambular por las ferias, dejando sus productos a los distintos puestos de venta. Esta asociación precisa de dinero para poder mejorar la calidad de sus productos, tomando en cuenta que la materia prima con la que realizan sus productos en muchos casos no reúnen las condiciones de calidad necesarias para competir en un mercado saturado y donde todos luchan por conseguir un comprador que les asegure un ingreso mensual para hacer frente a sus deudas y las responsabilidades de ser madre de familia.

loans.use: This organization needs the money to improve the quality of their products, taking into consideration that the raw materials they  use sometimes do not meet the quality standards needed to compete with the current market.

loans.name: Nohemí

texts.es:
Several years ago, Nohemi, with the desire to learn to make clothes for herself, started to help her friend, who taught her how to make and design clothing. Slowly Nohemi became more and more involved in helping her friend. After realizing that she could put together clothing on her own, she started her own business which makes her able to help her husband with the expenses of their 4 children. Eight years ago she started first mending clothes and then totally producing them.

Thanks to her perseverance as a seamstress, she has been successful. That is the reason why she currently has several orders to make uniforms for schools near her home. She is requesting a loan of USD $375 that she will repay within six months. With this money, Nohemi will be able to buy fabric and materials to be able to make the uniforms and thus make money to be able to maintain her children in school. Her oldest is attending a university and Nohemi truly wishes that he continue his studies.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Hace varios Años, que Noemí, con las ganas de aprender a fabricar ropa para ella. Comenzó a ayudarle a una amiga. Quien le enseñó todo lo que era necesario para poder elaborar y componer ropa. Poco a poco Nohemí se fue involucrando más y más a ayudarle a su amiga. Y después de darse cuenta que ella podía elaborar una prenda sola. Decidió comenzar su propio negocio que le permitiera poder ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos de sus 4 hijos. Hace 8 años que comenzó primero a reparar prendas y después a fabricarlas en su totalidad.

Gracias a su empeño como costurera Nohemí ah tenido éxito. Es por eso que actualmente tiene varios pedidos de uniformes para unas escuelas que están por su casa. Es por eso que Nohemí está solicitando un crédito de US $375 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Nohemí podrá comprar telas y material para poder elaborar sus uniformes y así poder sacar dinero para poder mantener a sus hijos estudiando. Puesto que Actualmente el mayor ya está en universidad y Nohemí desea que él siga estudiando.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for the making of clothing.

loans.name: Star Fish Group

texts.es:
Star fish are beings that live under the water and are known for their beauty and at the same time as a species that is in danger of extinction, same as the women that make up this group. Their decisiveness, perseverance and tenacity make them like the starfish, women that are hard to find in this day and age.

This society is made up to 17 partners that have been in the main center of Villa Adela.

Their main activity is the sale of handicrafts and textiles, hand made products, weaves, embroideries, finished products such as hats, blankets, shawls and others, which they sell in wholesale centers and markets. The majority do not have permanent stalls and have to rove from one space to another offering their products, in many cases on credit or on consignment, this being the only way for them to sell their products daily and meet their obligations.

Currently they are in need of funds to improve their products and buy sales stands, which will give them a better way to make sales and stop having to roam the streets selling sometimes without result. This way they can support their families, since the divorce rate among them is high and therefore the women function as mothers, fathers and financial supporters for their whole family.

Translated from Spanish by L. Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Las estrellas de mar, son seres que viven debajo del agua, y son muy apreciados por su belleza y al mismo tiempo por ser una de las especies en peligro de extinción, así como las mujeres que conforman esta sociedad. Su decisión, perseverancia y tenacidad, hacen de ellas al igual que las estrellas de mar, mujeres muy difíciles de encontrar hoy en día.

Esta asociación cuenta con 17 socias que se encuentran ya dos años dentro del centro Focal de Villa Adela.

Su principal actividad es la venta de artesanías y textiles, productos hechos a mano, tejidos, bordados, acabados, como sombreros, mantas, mantillas y otros que venden en centros de abasto o ferias. La mayoría no cuenta con puestos de venta fijo, por lo que se dedican a deambular por los puestos ofreciendo sus productos, en muchos casos al crédito o en consignación, únicas maneras de conseguir una venta diaria para hacer frente a sus obligaciones.

Actualmente ellas precisan de capital para poder mejorar sus productos, comprar puestos de venta, que es la manera más adecuada para poder vender y dejar de ambular por las calles, muchas veces sin éxito, y de esta manera poder llevar el sustento a sus hogares, tomando en cuenta que esta asociación tiene índices de divorcios altos, por tanto las mujeres fungen como madres, padres y gestores de recursos económicos para toda su familia.

loans.use: They are in need of funds to improve their products and buy sales stands, which will give them a better way to make sales and stop having to roam the streets selling sometimes without result.  This way they can support their families, since the divorce rate among them is high and therefore the women function as mothers, fathers and financial supporters for their whole family.

loans.name: Thi Dinh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dinh, 31 years old, lives in Trung Bạn village of township Chờ. She has two school age children. Her family’s been in carpentry business for many years. She’s been taking loans to expand the family’s business. All have been repaid. She’s recently referred to Binh Minh that she can apply for a loan of 150USD. The repayment schedule fits to her family’s daily income of 5USD very well.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Dinh, 31 tuổi, ở thôn Trung Bạn, Thị trấn Chờ, có hai con còn đang đi học. Gia đình chị làm nghề thợ mộc tại nhà từ nhiều năm nay. Để mở rộng sản xuất kinh doanh, chị đã từng vay họ hàng, nhưng giờ đã trả hết. Nay, được biết về những tiện ích của chương trình Tài chính Vi mô Binh minh cdc, chị mạnh dạn vay 2006000đ vì thấy hình thức trả dần rất phù hợp với việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị. Với thu nhập bình quân là 70.000 - 80.000đ/ngày, gia đình chị có thể dễ dàng trả nợ.

loans.use: Expand family's carpentry business

loans.name: Thi Hien

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hiên buys then sells stuff at the market. She also is a general labor for hire. On her spare time she helps her husband making furniture. She is 18, young and energetic. She has never taken out any loan before. This first time, she would like to apply for a loan of 150USD. Her daily income is 5USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hiên làm nghề đi chợ và làm thuê. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị từ 70.000-80.000đ/ngày. Mặc dù còn rất trẻ, mới 18 tuổi, nhưng chị rất năng động. Công việc chủ yếu của chị là đi chợ. Bên cạnh đó, mỗi khi rảnh rỗi, chị lại giúp chồng làm mộc, không thì chị đi làm thuê để có thể tăng thu nhập gia đình. Gia đình chị chưa vay ở đâu. Chị rất thích hình thức trả góp của chương trình Tài chính vi mô binh minh cdc và chị mạnh dạn vay 2006000đ để đi chợ và cho công việc làm mộc của chồng.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Thi Le

texts.vi:
Mrs Lệ, 27, lives in Trung Ban hamlet, Chờ town. Her family income is stable: she raises pigs & poultry and sells grocery at the market. Her income is 80.000-100.000 VND a day (5-6.25 USD a day). She never had a loan before. This time she applies to Binh Minh cdc (SEDA) because the loan term is favorable and accessible. She's requesting a loan of 125 USD to replendish her grocery inventory and buy chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lệ, 27 tuổi ở thôn Trung Ban, thị trấn Chờ. Hoạt động tạo thu nhập của gia đình chị khá đa dạng. Ngoài việc chăn nuôi gà, lơn, chị còn đi chợ bán thực phẩm vì vậy, thu nhập gia đình chị khá ổn định từ 80.000 - 100.000đ/ngày. Từ trước tới nay, chị chưa vay vốn ở đâu. Nay, chị vay của Chương trình Binhminh cdc vì điều kiện vay ở đây khá dễ dàng mà lại được trả góp hàng tuần. Với số tiền 2006000 đ vay được, chị sẽ dùng để đi chợ và chăn nuôi.

loans.use: buy grocery and chickens.

loans.name: Thi Hoi

texts.vi:
Mrs Hồi is 34. She sells sticky rice cake and and raises poultry to make ends meet. She is a widow so raising 2 children by herself is quite difficult. She makes 50000-80000 VND/day (3-5 USD/day). She has never borrowed money before. So when she learns of Binh Minh cdc (SEDA), she applies for a loan of 2006000 VND (150 USD) to buy ingredients for the rice cake.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hồi, 34 tuổi, làm nghề bán bánh tẻ và chăn nuôi. Chồng mất sớm, một mình chị nuôi 2 con ăn học, cuộc sống khá vất vả. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị từ 50000-80000đ/ngày. Chị chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu. Được biết tới hình thức trả góp hàng tuần của chương trình Tài chính vi mô binh minh cdc, chị rất thích và đã vay 2006000đ để thêm vốn lấy hàng

loans.use: buy ingredients to make rice cake

loans.name: Thi Hue

texts.vi:
Mrs Huê is 22. She has a young child. Her main occupation is selling grocery from home. She makes 3-5 USD a day. She has contracted a loan from lender before but she has repaid since then. Now she applies to SEDA for a loan of 150 USD because it is much simpler and the loan term is favorable. She will use the money to stock up her inventory thus raising her income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Huê, 22 tuổi, có 1 con nhỏ. Chị làm nghề bán hàng tạp hoá tại gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân từ 50000 - 80000đ/ngày. Trước, chị có vay ở ngoài, nhưng giờ đã trả hết. Nay, chị vay 2006000đ theo Chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì thủ tục vay ở đây khá đơn giản, lại được trả góp hàng tuần. Số tiền chị vay được, chị dùng để lấy thêm hàng bán, tăng thu nhập cho gia đình

loans.use: stock up inventory for her grocery store

loans.name: Abdurahmon

texts.en:
Abdurahmon A. is 30 years old. He is married and has four children; the oldest is ten, and the youngest is only two years old.

Abdurahmon manufactures carved wooden doors, window frames, and partitions in the national oriental style. He has been in this business for 14 years already. Abdurahmon also works 30 hectares of land, where he grows potatoes and carrots. During the planting season, his hardworking family helps him. In spite of his young age, he is recognized as a good workman in his neighborhood. Abdurahmon works hard and dreams of improving the living conditions of his family.

Today Abdurahmon is requesting a loan of 4,160 somoni ($1,200 in US dollars) to purchase wood products, such as bold timber and plank timber, for his manufacturing. He managed his previous loan without violations, and he promises to pay the current one on time.

loans.use: To purchase wood products for manufacturing carved wooden doors, window frames, and partitions

loans.name: Thi Chuyen

texts.vi:
Mrs Chuyền is 23. She is married and has 2 young children who are attending school. She sells meat at the market. Her husband runs a motorbike repair shop at home. Their daily income is 100000 VND (6.25 USD). She has contracted loans from lenders before but has repaid. She likes SEDA because she can pay in installments. She's requesting a loan of 150 USD to stock up her inventory thus raising her revenue in the long run.

Translated fron=m Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Chuyền, 23 tuổi, có 2 con đang còn đi học. Hàng ngày, chị đi chợ bán thịt còn chồng chị thì sửa xe máy tại nhà. Thu nhập bình quân hai vợ chồng chị là 100000đ/ngày. Chị đã từng vay vốn ở ngoài, nhưng nay đã trả hết. Chị thích vay theo Chương trình Tài chính vi mô Binhminh cdc hơn vì được trả dần hàng tuần. Với số tiền 2006000đ vay được, chị dùng để đi chợ, mua thêm nhiều thịt về để bán, tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.

loans.use: buy meat

loans.name: Raig

texts.en: Raig lives in the town of Sumgait together with his family - his wife and two children (a son and a daughter). He has been engaged in trade for 10 years now. He rents a small shop where he sells shoes of all kinds for men. He applied to the Sumgait branch of Normicro for his second loan now - the first one was successfully repaid in due time. He needs $1000 for 12 months in order to enhance the variety of shoes offered to his customers.

loans.use: To increase variety and quantity of goods

loans.name: Teresa José David

texts.pt:
Teresa José David L. is married with 5 children. She entered the program in 2006 with a loan of 3000MT. She is a farmer and has a sales stand in her house. She is asking for a loan of $275.00US to be paid back in 4 months so that she can enroll her children in school.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Teresa José David L., Portadora do BI nº100137760S Vive maritalmente tem 5 filhos entrou no programa em 2006 tomando o valor de 3000 mt é agricultora e tem uma barraca em sua casa ogra vai tomar 6000 a pagar em 4 meses o valor é para fazer a matricula dos seus filhos.

loans.use: Enroll her children in school

loans.name: Etibar

texts.en: Etibar is an Internally Displaced Person and was forced to flee his native region of Gubadli as a result of conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia. He lives now in Sumgait town. His family, which consists of his wife and 3 children support him in his entrepreneurial activities. His business has to do with women's clothing, which he sells at a local marketplace. Etibar applied to Sumgait branch of Normicro for the first time and he needs $600 to increase his business turnover. He wants to take the loan for 12 months.

loans.use: To buy new goods for sale

loans.name: Terlan

texts.en: Tarlan lives in Sumgait. He is married and has two little sons. His business is the production of furniture, which he has been running for 10 years now. He owns a small furniture workshop. Tarlan applied to Sumgait branch of Normicro for a loan. Tarlan needs additional capital to buy more timber as he has a lot of orders from his clients. He wants to borrow his first loan. Tarlan asks for is $500 for a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy materials (timber)

loans.name: Yahe

texts.en:
Yahe A. is 42 years old. He is married and has three children. Yahe's wife stays at home and takes care of the family.

Yahe is the main breadwinner in his large family. For ten years he has been selling carrots, cabbages, potatoes, and garlic in the center of the biggest market in the city. Yahe has many clients every day, so the business generates a stable income for his family all year.

Yahe has received loans from IMON several times and had shown himself to be a reliable client. Today Yahe requests 3,450 somoni ($1,000.00 in US dollars), to increase his stock of goods to sell in the market. He requests this loan for the term of nine months.

loans.use: To increase his stock of goods, such as carrots, cabbages, potatoes, and garlic, to sell in the market

loans.name: Ziver

texts.en: Zivar lives in the suburbs of Sumgait with her family – her husband and two children. She has been engaged in business for 10 years now. She specializes in selling assorted food stuffs and sales have been on the rise recently. Zivar applied to Sumgait branch of Normicro as she needs to buy a cash machine for her shop. This is a requirement of the tax authorities as she has to use her own money for the turnover capital. For that she needs $500 for 12 months.

loans.use: To buy a cash machine

loans.name: Henriqueta Sebastião

texts.pt:
Henriqueta Sebastião M. is married and has 3 children. She raises Chickens. She entered the program with a group and borrowed $75.00, and now she is doing it alone. She is in the 3rd cycle and is asking for $350.00 to be paid back in 4 months. She will use the money to invest in raising chickens.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Henriqueta Sebastião M., portador do BI nº110259766C vive maritalmente tem 3 filhos é criadora de Pintos entrou no programa como grupo e tomava 1800 ,a gora esta a levar so esta no 3 coclo vai tomar o valor de 8000 a para em 4 meses valor é para investir na criação de pintos

loans.use: Purchase chickens

loans.name: Nalweruba A(I) Group

texts.en:
Juliet is 36 years old and married with four children. She makes and sells snacks (e.g., chapatis, samosas, etc.) for a living. With the increased business profits, she intends to pay school fees for her children and also buy a plot of land. Edith has a restaurant business. Betty sells raw food in the market and wants to use the loan to expand her business. Jesca and Madina sell second-hand clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand businesses selling snacks and raw foodstuffs

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
For eight years, Uktam A. has been raising cattle, as well as growing potatoes and carrots. He has 15 hectares of land. His wife and oldest son help him during the planting season. He also manufactures wooden plows. In his village, this wooden plow is very popular, because it is affordable for the residents of this rural area. Uktam is planning to spend the income he generates from these activities to pay the fees for the education of his children, as he has three of them. 

Uktam is planning to purchase two cows for breeding. He also wants to improve the winter conditions for his cattle, because  this year it is unusually cold in Tajikistan. For this purpose, Uktam requests $900 for the term of 12 months. This is his second loan, and the previous one was managed accurately.

loans.use: To purchase two cows and to improve the winter conditions for his cattle

loans.name: Filomena José

texts.pt:
Filomena José M. is married with 5 children. She entered the program March 1, 2007 with a loan of $150.00US. She is now in her 3rd cycle and is asking for $275.00US to be paid back in 6 months. She sells yogurt, milk, crackers, and cookies, and she makes deliveries on orders as well. This loan will be invested into her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Filomena José M., portador do BI nº 110714284N Casada com 5 filhos entrou no programa a 1/03/07 tomava o volor de 3000 agora esta no 3º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 6000 para pagar em 6 meses é negociante vende yoguertes leites biscoitos bolachas e o seu negocio faz entrega por incomendas o valor vai investir no negocio

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Khalimachon

texts.en:
Khalimachon A. is 41 years old. She is married and has three children.

Khalimachon runs her own tailoring shop. Currently there are four sewers working in the shop. Khalimachon’s tailoring shop specializes in sewing clothing for women in both the European style and the national style. Khalimachon's husband is not employed, so her business is the main source of income for her family.

Khalimachon is planning to expand her business and to hire two more sewers. She requests a loan of 3,450 somoni ($1,000.00 in US dollars) for the term of nine months. She will use the loan to purchase a new sewing machine produced in Japan. This is Khalimachon's first loan; however, she would like to assure everyone that she will be able to pay it on time.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine to help expand her business

loans.name: Claúdia Olimpia

texts.pt:
Claúdia Olimpia D. is married with 4 children. She is now entering the program and is asking for a loan of $150.00US to be paid back in 4 months. She sells staple products and intends to also sell hamburger.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Claúdia Olimpia D., portadora do BI nº 110319488B casada com 4 filhos esta a entra no programa e vai tomar o valor de 3000 a pagar em 4 meses é negociante vende produtos de 1º necessidade e pretende fazer um Take away para vender hamburguer.

loans.use: Invest in the business

loans.name: Rabeca

texts.pt:
Rabeca C. is married and has 3 children. She is now entering the program and is asking for a loan of $275.00US for 4 months. She sells new clothes brought from South Africa, and she sells them on foot. She will use the money to invest in her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Rabeca C., portadora do BI nº 0016257220 vive maritalmente tem 3 filhos esta a entrar no programa vai tomar o valor de 6000 apagar em 4 meses é negociante vende roupas novas trazidas da Africa do Sul e faz venda ambulante com o valor vai investir no negocio.

loans.use: Invest in the business

loans.name: Nalweruba A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and married with five children. She sells used clothes for a living. She wants to use the extra business profits to buy a piece of land and build a residential house. Hadijah and Jolly sell charcoal and want to use the loan to expand their businesses. Fausta sells roasted maize.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale and to expand other businesses

loans.name: Maria Dolorosa José

texts.pt:
Maria Dolorosa José S., bearer of ID number 110082821Z, is married and the mother of 5 children. She joined the program on November 11, 2006, with an initial loan of 5000 MT, and is now on her 3rd loan. She is requesting 8000 MT, to be repaid in 6 months. Maria has a beauty salon in the Compone market, and she intends to use this loan toward purchasing beauty products.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer

Maria Dolorosa José S., portador do BI nº 110082821Z , casada com 5 filhos entrou no programa a 17/11/06 tomou o valor de 5000 agora esta no 3º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 8000 a pagar em 6 meses tem um Salão de Beleza no mercado Compone o volor pretende aplicar na compra de Produtos de Beleza.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Katogo C(I) Group

texts.en:
Jalia is 33 years old and married with three children. Her current business is selling used clothes. With the extra business profits, she intends to buy a piece of land and pay school fees for the children. Mastula sells fruits and vegetables and wants to use the loan to expand business. Imelda has a retail shop while Jane sells second hand shoes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Katogo C(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Hope is 35 year old widow with two children. The children all go to school. He sells used shoes for a living. Hope usually earns shs 35,000 in profits each week. She wants her children to have a good quality education. She wants to use the extra business profits to open up bank accounts for the children and start saving for them money for their education. Sumini and Mariam sell crafts while Juliet sells soft drinks.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Katogo C(Iii) Group

texts.en:
Betty is 32 years old and married with three children. The husband is a business man. Betty has a restaurant business. With the extra profits, she wants to open up a poultry business for her father. Mary and Mastula are poultry farmers and want to use the loan to expand the business. Jane sells second hand clothes while Mary has a retail shop business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To  buy food warmers

loans.name: Katogo C(Iv) Group

texts.en:
Justine is 48 years and divorced with five children. Justine and Swabula have retail shop business. With the extra business profits, Justine wants to expand her business and become a wholesaler. She also wants to build for her children a permanent residential house. Sumaya, Jane and Agnes all sell second hand clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock in the retail shop

loans.name: Katogo A(I) Group

texts.en:
Regina is a 48 year old widow with seven children. Only one child goes to school. Her current business is chicken roasting. Regina sees a business opportunity of starting up her own poultry farm to reduce the costs of buying chicken. She wants to use the extra profits to buy a plot of land and construct as house for orphans. Irene and Jalia sell second hand clothes and want to use the loan to increase stock. Margret has a grocery store while Teo sells raw foods in the market.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more chicken

loans.name: Teles António

texts.pt:
Teles António L., bearer of ID number 110378439S, is married and has 5 children. He joined the program on October 3, 2006, and is now on his 3rd loan. He is requesting 6000 MT, to be repaid in 6 months. He intends to invest the money in purchasing goods and repairing his house. He is a hard worker.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer.

Teles António L., portador do BI nº110378439S vive maritalmente tem 5 filhos entrou no programa a 3/10/06 agora esta no 3º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 6000 a pagar em 6 meses o valor vai investir na compra de bens e reforma da sua casa. ele é trabalhador

loans.use: Purchase goods and repair home

loans.name: Katogo A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Ritah is 30 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a teacher. Sarah has a beauty salon and parlor. She sees a business opportunity of opening up another salon in the city centre. She wants to use the extra profits to buy a piece of and for her children. Saidat sells crafts and wants to use the loan to expand business. Beatrice makes and sells snacks while Sumini offers catering services.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more hair dryers

loans.name: Katogo A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
Lukia is 48 years old and married with fifteen children. Her husband is a hotel attendant. Lukia sells charcoal for a living. She usually earns shs 30,000 in profits each week. With the extra business profits, she intends to buy a plot of land and construct a house for her family. Lazia has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase stock. Irene is a poultry farmer while Jane makes and sells snacks.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Odete Alberto

texts.pt:
Odete Alberto M., bearer of ID number 110255407P, is married and has 3 children. She joined the program on October 28, 2005 and is on her 6th loan. She is requesting 15000 MT, to be repaid in 6 months. She plans to invest the money in her business of selling staple goods such as eggs, oil, etc.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer.

Odete Alberto M., portadora do BI nº 110255407P vive maritalmente tem 3 filhos entrou no programa a 28/10/05 esta no 6º coclo vai tomar o valor de 15000 apagar em 6 meses com o valor vai investir no negocio ela vende produtos de 1º necessidade tais como ovos oleo etc.

loans.use: Purchase products

loans.name: Katogo B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and married with six children. The husband is a builder. Jane offers tailoring services. She wants to use the extra business profits to pay back the loan and expand the tailoring business. Sarah is a poultry farmer while Solome sells raw foods in the market.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines

loans.name: Katogo B(I) Group

texts.en:
Kasifa is 28 years old and married with three children. She has a poultry business. With the extra business profits, she wants to buy for herself a plot of land.Sarah has a beauty parlor. Hanifa and Sarah both sell second hand clothes and want to use the loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed.

loans.name: Katogo A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
Milly is 35 years old and divorced with two children. One of the children goes to school. Milly sells second hand clothes. With the extra business profits, she wants to  open up a bank account and start saving money. Fina is a poultry farmer and wants to use the loan to buy a water tank. Fase offers tailoring services and wants to buy an electronic sewing machine with the loan. Justine sells charcoal while Robinah sells used shoes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase the stock of clothes.

loans.name: Abida's Group

texts.en:
I am Abida R. and I live in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. I have five children, three boys and two girls, all quite young. My husband makes a living driving a donkey cart that is owned by someone else, and would like to buy his own cart. Doing this will allow us to greatly increase our income, because most of the money he makes goes to the owner of the cart.

I lead a group of women who live in my area, all of whom are very responsible and cooperative. Sughran B. needs a loan to buy a rickshaw. Shazia B. will use the loan to pay off the remaining installments on her rickshaw. Naseem B. needs a loan to expand her produce-selling business. Sarwer B.'s husband runs a grocery store; she will use her portion of the loan to restock it.

loans.use: Buy a donkey cart and other items needed by several small businesses

loans.name: Katogo B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
Milly has a retail shop business. She usually earns shs 30,0000 in profits weekly. She wants to use the extra profits to buy a piece of land. Sarah and Agnes have beauty salons and want to use the loan to expand their businesses. Suzan offers laundry services and wants to use the loan to buy a generator.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock in her retail shop.

loans.name: Balqees' Group

texts.en:
My name is Balqees A. and my group and I are applying for our second loan. My husband manufactures furniture for a living, and one of my sons sells shoes. We need a loan to expand both of these businesses.

The members of my loan group are: Razia B., who will invest the loan in her restaurant. Sughran B. needs this loan for her grocery store. Razia A. requires this loan for her husband, who is an electrician and needs to buy some machinery. Shazia B. wants to buy a cow. Kalsoom B. will buy a rickshaw for her son.

I completely trust these women and want to help them make their businesses and their lives better.

loans.use: Expand several small businesses

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en: I am Parween A. from Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. I have lived all my life in this town. My husband operates an electronics store. Now, he requires a loan to buy some items for his electronics store.  I would like to borrow in a group of few women: Nasreen A. needs loan to buy goats for their livestock trading. Rubina B. wants to open up a grocery store. Nargis B. will use the loan for the repair of their rickshaw. Saleema B. also wants a loan for her son’s grocery store. Rahima B. is a widow and sells cloth.

loans.use: Expand electronics store

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en: I am Parween A. from Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. I have lived all my life in this town. My husband operates an electronics store. Now, he requires a loan to buy some items for his electronics store.  I would like to borrow in a group of few women: Nasreen A. needs loan to buy goats for their livestock trading. Rubina B. wants to open up a grocery store. Nargis B. will use the loan for the repair of their rickshaw. Saleema B. also wants a loan for her son’s grocery store. Rahima B. is a widow and sells cloth.

loans.use: Expand electronics store

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en: I am Parween A. from Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. I have lived all my life in this town. My husband operates an electronics store. Now, he requires a loan to buy some items for his electronics store.  I would like to borrow in a group of few women: Nasreen A. needs loan to buy goats for their livestock trading. Rubina B. wants to open up a grocery store. Nargis B. will use the loan for the repair of their rickshaw. Saleema B. also wants a loan for her son’s grocery store. Rahima B. is a widow and sells cloth.

loans.use: Expand electronics store

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en: I am Parween A. from Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. I have lived all my life in this town. My husband operates an electronics store. Now, he requires a loan to buy some items for his electronics store.  I would like to borrow in a group of few women: Nasreen A. needs loan to buy goats for their livestock trading. Rubina B. wants to open up a grocery store. Nargis B. will use the loan for the repair of their rickshaw. Saleema B. also wants a loan for her son’s grocery store. Rahima B. is a widow and sells cloth.

loans.use: Expand electronics store

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en:
My name is Parween A. and I have lived my entire life in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. My husband operates an electronics store and we have applied for this loan so we can buy new items for him to sell.

I am applying for this loan with five other women: Nasreen A. needs a loan to buy goats for her livestock-trading business. Rubina B. wants to open up a grocery store. Nargis B. will use the loan to repair her family's rickshaw. Saleema B. wants a loan for her son’s grocery store. Rahima B. is a widow who sells cloth and will use the loan to buy more fabric.

loans.use: Expand an electronics store and various other small businesses

loans.name: Mukisa Group

texts.en: N. Speranza has been our client for the last 4 years and she is the chairperson of Mukisa Group, which will share in this loan. She is married with 4 children and cares for 3 brothers and 3 sisters. She operates a canteen at Tiger Army School, Mubende with students as her customers. She has serviced loans of $250 and her current loan is $150. She has benefited by building her own house. She also has a piggery business and rears local chicken. She plans to increase the number of pigs and expand her canteen to be able to build her parents a house, continue paying school fees for her children as well as cater for her dependents. With her leadership skills and commitment, she can achieve her goal.

loans.use: Natabi Speranza intends to increase the stock in her canteen by buying bread, yellow bananas, washing soap and sodas.

loans.name: Finore

texts.en: Finore E. raises cattle in the small northeastern Azerbaijani town of Devechi. She is married with three children and has been working in this business for the last twelve years. She has already successfully repaid one prior loan with Norwegian Microcredit in the amount of $800. She is currently looking for funding so that she can purchase more calves to raise for slaughter and milk production.

loans.use: To purchase more calves for her business

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
I am Shamim A., wife of Habib Saqib. I live with my family in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. My loan group and I are borrowing for the first time. My husband runs a pharmacy and we need a loan to buy medicines to sell. This is a small town and there are not many pharmacies here, so business is good.

I am also requesting help for the members of my group, all of whom are mutually responsible for each other's loans. Jinda B. wants a loan for her laundry. Yasmeen B. needs a loan for her pet shop. Zarina B. sells milk for a living, and needs a loan to buy more supplies to sell. Zulakhan B.’s husband runs a grocery store which needs new inventory. Arshad B. manufactures bicycle seats and needs the loan to improve her business.

loans.use: Buy medicines for a pharmacy and other items for various small businesses

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
I am Nusrat A. and I live in the small city Borofewala, Pakistan. I am applying for my second loan. Last year, my husband and I took out a loan to invest in the snack stand he operates in a nearby market. This year, we are applying for a loan to buy a rickshaw, which he would like to rent out to various drivers. We hope that with this venture, our income will double. I am a mother of four children, two girls and two boys, all of whom are in school.

I lead a group which includes the following women: Fareeda B., who needs a loan to help her brother supply eggs to different shops in our city. Zahida P. needs the loan for her bicycle repair shop. Manzooran B. will use the loan to improve her crockery store. Khursheed B. wants to buy oranges to sell from her cart. Please help all of us.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw and other items for various small businesses

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en: Miss Chantha D., 29, and her sister, 26, are single. They live with their parents in Koh Dach Iceland by the Mekong River. They and their mother sell groceries in the village to the nearby people. She and her sister cannot finish primary school because the family is not able to support them. Chantha is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the fifth time, this time in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her stock

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
I am Salma B. and my husband's name is Sohail Khalid. I have five children, three boys and two girls. My husband and one of my sons run a store where they sell cement and other construction materials. They have been in this business for a number of years, and we are applying for a loan to expand their business.

My loan group includes three other women. Salma I.’s son operates a lathe and requires a loan to expand his business. Nargis P. needs this loan for her husband’s shoe store. Sardaran B. needs loan for her son's business. I want all of these women to get loans so that they can improve their families’ incomes and lives.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies we need to expand our businesses

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: N. Kong married in 1982 and has three sons and two daughters. She started selling vegetables in 2000. Her husband is a construction worker, while their oldest son is a garment worker and the others are studying in the local school. She and her husband were not able to finish primary school because of the war. However, they are very kind, friendly and honest. The family lives in Koh Oknhathei by the Mekong River. Kong is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the fifth time, this time in the amount of $800, to buy more vegetables such as onions, cauliflower, bitter gourds, and beans. She also plans to add some meat and fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
My name is Shamim H. and I was born in the small town of Pakpattan but now live in Borewala, Pakistan with my family. I need a loan to buy my son a rickshaw. My husband is a rickshaw driver and has trained our boy in this trade. Therefore, I feel that my son will do well with a rickshaw of his own.

I am the leader of a group that includes four other women. We are all committed to eradicate poverty in our community. Noor B. wants a loan for her son’s cotton-trading business. Hanifa B. needs a loan so her son can supply flour to various shops in our city. Amna B.’s husband runs a canteen and wants to buy furniture for it. Sabra B. will use her portion of the loan to start a small shoe-making business.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw and other supplies for various businesses

loans.name: Semire

texts.en: Semire E. and her family are cattle raisers in the northeastern Azerbaijani town of Devechi. She has been working in this business for the last eleven years and currently wants to expand her and her family’s business. Semire has already successfully repaid two prior loans with Norwegian Microcredit, proving to be one of our valued and trusted customers. She is looking for funding in the amount of $1,500 so that she can purchase more calves to raise for slaughter and milk production.

loans.use: To purchase calves to raise for slaughter and milk production

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Sokheng, 52, is a widow. She lives with her seven children, two boys and five girls, along national road number 1 to Nak Loeurng and the Vietnam border. She and one of her daughters have sold fruit since 1995. Three other daughters work in the garment factory, one son works as a construction worker and another is studying. Sokheng has finished grade two in primary school, but her daughter cannot read and write properly. She is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA, in the amount amount of $1,200, to buy fruit in bulk and sell it to the middle man in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To buy more fruit

loans.name: Balqees' Group

texts.en:
My name is Balqees A. and I live in Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. I am married and the mother of four boys. My oldest son is working while all the others are still in school. My husband supports our family by selling cooking utensils from a cart. We will use our portion of the loan to buy utensils in bulk. 

There are two other women in my loan group, and I am  guarantor of these women and ensure you they will repay this loan on time. Parween B. is borrowing money to help her son set up a restaurant. Rasheeda B. will invest her portion of the loan in her son’s motorcycle repair shop.

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils and other items in bulk

loans.name: Gulnure

texts.en: Gulnure S. raises cattle with her family in the northeastern Azerbaijani town of Devechi. Gulnure is 20 years old and married with one child and has been working in this business for the last three years. She is currently looking for funding so that she and her family can purchase more calves to raise for slaughter and milk production.

loans.use: To purchase calves to raise for slaughter and milk production

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en: Vannak and his wife, Koh Sophak, live in Koh Brak along the Mekong River. He married in 1998 and has three children, one son and two daughters. The son and one of the daughters are studying in primary school, and the youngest one is too young to study. He works as a teacher while his wife is a housewife. Vannak is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, this time in the amount of $600, to buy a new motorbike to use as a transport to work.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mr. Vannak Rous has enough money to pay off his loan early before contract.

Thank you.

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en:
My name is Jameela L. S. and I am the mother of seven children. My husband makes a living selling fruit from a cart, and we have applied for a loan to buy fruit in bulk for him to sell. I am the leader of a group made up of four other women and am responsible for their loans. All of us live in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. 
My group members are: Nasreen B., who wants a loan to repair her family's rickshaw. Khursheed B.’s husband is a builder who needs to buy construction equipment. S. B. will invest the loan in her food stall and buy dried fruits in bulk. Zubaida B. needs this loan to buy some items she needs for her family's business selling sweets and candies.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for five small businesses

loans.name: Mirsaid

texts.en:
Mirsaid C. is 30 years old. He is married and has two children.

Mirsaid sells rice in the largest local market of the city. He has been in this business for six years already, during which time he has become an expert in rice. It should be mentioned that rice is very popular in Tajikistan. One of the most widely spread meals, called “plov,” is made with rice. Plov is cooked very often; you can hardly find any family occasion that can be conducted without that delicious meal. There are various types of plov, and each depends upon the meat and the rice that are used for cooking. So Mirsaid is not only a seller but also a rather important person for his customers, as he is ready to give good advice in choosing the type of rice.

Today Mirsaid requests 3,450 somoni ($1,000 in US dollars) for the term of nine months. He shall use the loan to purchase rice to sell. This is his second loan with IMON. The previous one was managed accurately without delinquencies or violations. Mirsaid thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To increase his stock of rice to sell

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny and her family live in Preak Smey Commune about 12 km from Phnom Penh. She married in 1979 and has six children. She started selling bananas, vegetables, and mangoes in 1998, and her husband, Sorn Leng, is a cook for wedding ceremonies. Three of her children help her in selling fruit and the others are students. She and her husband were less educated than their children are because of the past family condition and war. Mrs. Ny is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $800 to buy mangoes in bulk and sell them in both Phnom Penh and the village.

loans.use: To buy mangoes in bulk

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba C. is 24 years old. In spite of her young age, she is already the mother of two wonderful kids and is a real expert in her business.

Nasiba produces jewelry in the national style. She has been in this business for nine years already. Nasiba started as an assistant to a goldsmith; however, with time she has gained enough experience to be able to run her own shop. Nasiba’s husband is a lawyer; however, Nasiba’s business brings a substantial income to the family budget.

Nasiba has received loans from IMON for several years and has proven herself to be an honest client. Today Nasiba requests $1,000 to purchase input materials such as fragments, precious and semi-precious stones, and reagents, to use in manufacturing jewelry.

loans.use: To purchase materials such as fragments, precious and semi-precious stones, and reagents, for making jewelry

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en: Mrs. Sreymom and her husband live in Koh Dach Iceland on the Mekong River. She married in 1993 and has six children, two girls and four boys. She learned weaving from her mother and started to weave in 1990. Thereafter she taught her husband to weave, too. Four of her children study at the school in the village, but the others are still very young. She buys material and sells finished products to the middle man, through which she can generate $3 in income per day. Sreymom is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the seventh time, this time in the amount of $300 to buy silk materials and sewing thread and pay other costs for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials and sewing thread

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Mrs. A. Chun and her family live in Preak Ampil Commune along the Mekong River. She married in 1960 and has only one daughter. She and her husband, Sok Buk, are farmers. They grow tomatoes, papaya, and eggplant in Koh Tang on the Mekong River, while her daughter sells Chinese noodles and coffee at home. 
She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, this time in the amount of $1,000 to buy a new small tractor for plowing.

loans.use: To purchase a small tractor

loans.name: Sifatbonu

texts.en:
Sifatbonu C. is 43 years old. She is raising two children alone.

Sifatbonu has been breeding cattle for six years. She sells the cattle in the local market. Currently she has three cows. This business generates a stable income, which is the main source of income for the family. Sifatbonu's older son is 18 years old and helps his mother.

Today Sifatbonu requests $350. She is going to use the loan to purchase a cow. Having proved herself a reliable client , Sifatbonu promises that she shall pay the loan in 12 months, and she thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Savy

texts.en: Mrs. Savy was married in 1991 and has three children who are all studying in the primary and high school. She sells dessert in front of her house to the students and people of the village, while her husband drives a motor taxi in Phnom Penh. They live in Dey Eth Commune along national road number one, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $800 to fix their house, where she makes her desserts to sell.

loans.use: To fix the house

loans.name: Lidia Da Graca

texts.pt:
Lidia da Graca is single and has a 4-year-old child. She does not live with the father of her child because he has a wife and children. She ended her relationship with him because he would not take her on as his wife. Besides her son, Lidia also has a nephew living with her, who is her younger sister’s son.

Lidia lives in Inhamissa, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the city of Xai-Xai.

Lidia is on her 3rd loan. Because she lives in a somewhat rural area, she was not attracting as many customers as she would like. So she decided to begin another business selling beauty products such as jewelry, perfume, gloss, lipstick, eyeliner, etc. This new business has drawn many clients. For that reason she will temporarily stop her hair salon business so that she can invest most of the money from the loan in purchasing beauty products, since it brings in more profit. Lidia purchases her products in the neighboring country of South Africa twice a month, because such products are cheaper there than in Mozambique. She spends 9,000.00 MT on purchases and about 450 Randes for each round trip.

Lidia takes her beauty products from place to place where most of her customers are. She sells her products on credit, and then collects the debts at the end of each month. However she faces some problems in this process because not all the customers pay on the agreed-upon dates. These late payments affect her planned buying trips to South Africa, which many times she has had to postpone for one or two weeks. But she has slowly been able to get around this problem due to the loan granted by Kiva through FDM. She has paid off her FDM loans in a timely manner, and now wants to take out another one.

Lidia sees many positive changes in her life. She plans to open a small boutique where she can sell her products without having to circulate from place to place. She also thinks about improving her house. Lidia says one day she might marry a man if he agrees to live with her and take on her son. But otherwise she prefers to live alone.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva volunteer.

Lidia da Graca e solteira mas tem um filho de 4 anos. Ela nao vive com o pai de seu filho porque este tem esposa e filhos.Ela ja terminou o relacionamento com ele, porue nao a quis assumir como esposa.Para alem do filho ela vive com o sobrinho, filho de uma irma mais nova.Ela vive em Inhamissa um dos bairros perifericos da cidade de Xai-Xai.Lidia da Graca esta agora no terceiro ciclo de emprestimo. Pelo facto de ela viver numa zona um pouco rural. ela nao consegue ter tantos clientes como seria de desejar. Assim sendo ela resolveu iniciar um outro negocio que e o da venda de artigos de beleza a saber, joais, perfumes, vernizes, batons, lapis de sombraetc. Com este novo negocio ela conseguiu angariar muitos clientes. Neste contexto ela diz que vai parar por uns tempos com o salao de cabeleireiro. Assim a maior parte do emprestimo sera investido na compra de artigos de beleza, porque e o negocio que esta a render-lhe mais.Ela adquir os produtos de beleza num Pais vizinho a Republica da Africa do Sul. Ela viaja duas vezes por mes para a compra destes produtos por serem mais baratos naquele Pais do que no nosso. Ela gasta 9.000,00 Mt na compra destes produtos e paga pelo transporte de ida e volta por cada viagem cerca de 450 Randes.Estes artigos de beleza ela os vende de reparticao em reparticao onde estao a maior parte dos seus clientes. Ela faz a venda dos artigoa a credito e no fim do mes ela faz a cobranca dos valores em divida. So que neste processo ela enfrenta alguns problemas pois que nem todos os clientes pagam nas datas acordadas. Isso tem reflexos no seu programa de viagens, pois que muitas vezes tem de adiar a viagem para a RSA por uma ou duas semanas porque algumas clientes so pagam uma ou duas semanas depois da data acordad. Mas aos poucos ela esta conseguindo contornar isso devido ao emprestimo que lhe foi concedido pelo KIVA atraves do FDM.Ela reembolsar ao FDM todo o dinheiro dentro da do prazo que foi acordado. Assim ela quer obter um outro emprestimo. A sua vida esta a registar muitas mudancas positivas. Ela planeia abrir uma pequena boutique onde vendera os seus artigos em em vez de ter que circular de reparticao em reparticao. Por outro lado pensa tambem em melhorar a sua habitacao.

Lidia diz que um dia podera juntase a um homem que queira viver com ela e que assuma o seu filho. Porque de contrario ela prefere viver sozinha. Lidia da Graca

loans.use: Lidia wants to use the money to purchase beauty products and accessories

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng, 46, has seven children, four boys and two girls. She was married in 1985. She and her husband, Keom Hoeurn, are farmers. They grow papaya, corn and tomatoes, while their two daughters work in the garment factory and the sons are studying. They live in Koh Auknhathey by the Mekong River. Neither finished primary school; however, they are friendly and very polite. She and her husband are requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the sixth time, this time in the amount of $1,000 to pay the land rental fee and buy seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To pay the land rental fee and buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Mrs. Yim, 43, has been married since 1988 and has six children, two boys and four girls. She has sold boiled corn and Khmer cake since 2000. Meanwhile, her husband, Meach Rous, is a construction worker. Four of the children are studying while one of them works in the garment factory and the last one stays at home. The family lives in Koh Brak along the Mekong River. Mrs. Yim is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time in the amount of $1,200 to fix their house, where they work, and build a new bathroom and toilet.

loans.use: To fix the house

loans.name: Katogo B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
Eva is 33 years old and married with four children. She has a butcher shop. She wants to use the extra profits to buy a plot of land and construct a house.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand butchery business

loans.name: Bukasa A(I) Group

texts.en:
Aisha is a 43 year old widow of four children. She has a poultry business. With the extra business profits, she wants to pay school fees for her children. Chrissy has a carpentry workshop and wants to use the loan to expand business. Zahara has a beauty parlor. Viola has a grocery store and wants to increase stock with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed.

loans.name: Valina Joao

texts.pt:
Valina is not legally married, but lives with a man with whom she has 3 children. Her husband is a truck driver for a private company. The family lives in the administrative post of Chonguene, which is about 15 kilometers from Xai-Xai, and is where Valina has her business. Intially Valina’s husband was FDM’s client, but they decided that the husband should leave the business to Valina so he could take on the job as a truck driver. So, Valina has run the business since March 2007 and the business has grown. She has already repaid her first 9-month loan taken out in March, and now she wants a second one. She is an honest person and has always made her payments on time. Many things have changed in Valina’s life. She had such good results from the first loan that that she was able to open another stand for selling staple goods, improve her home, and says that she is really happy for having received the loan. If the business continues to do well, she and her husband plan on building a better quality home. Valina’s children, except the youngest one, are in school, and if everything goes well with building their house, the couple plans on legally marrying.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer.

Lidia nao casou oficialmente , mas vive com um homem com quem tem 3 filhos. O marido de Valina e motorista de um camiao, pertencente a um privado. Valina e sua familia vivem no Posto administrativo de Chongoene, que dista da cidade de Xai-xai cerca de 15 Kms. Valina exerce o seu negocio em Chongoene. Inicialmente quem era cliente do FDM era o marido de Valina mas o casal resolveu que o marido deveria deixar de fazer negocio e deixar essa tarefa para Valina, enquanto ele se empregaria como motorista num privado que lhe convidara. Assim Valina assumiu o negocio.desde Marco de 2007.Desde entao o negoci esta a crescer. Ela tomou o primeiro emprestimo em Marco por 9 meses. Ela conseguiu reembolsar o valor emprestado, agora quer tomar um outro. Ela tem bom caracter, pois que sempre pagou pontualmente a sua divida.Muita coisa mudou na vida de Valina. Com o emprestimo anterior ela conseguiu bons rendimentos de tal sorte que conseguiu abrir mais uma barraca onde vende tambem produtos de primeira necessidade, melhorou a sua habitacao, e diz que se sente muito feliz por ter recebido o emprestimo. Se o negocio continuar a correr bem como ate entao ela e o marido pensam construir uma casa com material convencional , pois que a que tem foi construida com material local. Os filhos de Valina a excepcao do mais nvo estao a estudar no ensino basico. Se tudo correr bem e conseguirem concluir a casa que planeiam construir, o casal ira regularizar a sua situacao matrimonial.

loans.use: Valina wants to use the money to purchase products for her small store.

loans.name: Bukasa A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Edith is 37 years old and married with three children. She sells charcoal for a living. She wants to use the extra business profits to buy a plot of land and build a house. Zamu and Faridah sell second hand clothes while Rose sells soft drinks.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Bukasa A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
Robinah is a 33 year old widow with two children. She runs a medical clinic and drug shop. She wants to use the extra business profits to pay her children's tuition fees at university. Gloria and Florence have retail shop businesses and want to use the loan to increase stock. Bena sells second hand clothes while Alice sells first hand shoes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs

loans.name: Herminia Da Cruz

texts.pt:
Herminia Da Cruz Vitorino lives with her partner and four children in the neighborhood of Nhancondo, in Maxixe, Mozambique. All four of her kids are enrolled in school. She started a business of raising and selling chicken to help her husband with the household expenses, which were getting to be too much for him to cover on his own. She joined the program in November of 2007 and used her first loan to double the number of chickens in her coop. Herminia plans to use her second loan to buy feed and vaccine for the chickens. If things keep going well, she plans to buy a car to help with the transportation needs of the business, which include the transport of chickens to the market where they are sold to the public.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva volunteer.

Herminia e solteira mas vive com um homem com quem tem 4 filhos. O marido de herminia e trabalhar numa Instituicao do Estado. Ele recebe cerca de $125. Com este salario ele enfrenta alguns problemas para sustentar a sua familia. Por isso Herminia teve que comecar a fzer negocio para apoir o seu marido nas despesas da casa. Herminia e sua familia vivem em Nhancondo, no Municipio da Maxixe. Ela cria frangos na sua residencia para a venda.Herminia tomou um primeiro emprestimo em Novembro de 2007. Ela conseguiu reembolsar todo o dinheiro pedido. e sem problemas porque sempre pagou pontualmente a sua divida. Assim ela quer pedir um outro emprestimo para a compra de vacinas e racao para os pintos, pois que ela aumentou a quantidade de 500 para 1000 pintos.Isso aconteceu graca ao emprestimo que ela tomou. Ela esta muito feliz por ter conseguido o emprestimo, sem ele talvez estivesse a enfrentar muitas dificuldades para repor o stock de pintos. Assim ela pensa em continuar por muito mais tempo a trabalhar com o FDM e com o KIVA.Os filhos de Herminia estao todos a estudar. Os mais velhos estao no ensino Secundario e os dois mais novos estao no ensino primario basico. SE o negocio continuar a correr bem num futuro ainda que a longo prazo ela e o seu companheiro pensam em comprar uma carrinha que lhes facilitara as deslocaoes para a compra de racao, transporte dos frangos ate ao mercado, incluindo a aquisicao dos proprios pintos.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and vaccine

loans.name: Horacio Juliao

texts.pt:
Horacio Juliao L. lives with his partner and two children in the city of Xai-Xai, Mozambique. His wife takes care of their small piece of land, growing greens and vegetables to help feed the family, while he is in the business of manufacturing and selling leather shoes at a street stand. His business is doing well, particularly since profits associated with his first loan cycle allowed him to build a "wood and mud" two-bedroom house with a veranda. Horacio is now requesting a loan of $775 to open a store in the semi-commercial neighborhood of Chiquelene, where more people will be able to appreciate and buy the shoes he makes. Part of the money will also go toward hiring one employee to help him run the business. According to Horacio, joining the credit program has brought many positive changes to his and his family's lives.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva volunteer.

Horacio nao casou oficialmente, mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 2 filhos. A mulher de Horacio toma conta da casa e trabalha na machamba familiar para a subsistencia de sua familia. Horacio esta muito satisfeito porque o seu negocio esta a crescer.Ele tomou um emprestimo em Outubro do ano passado. Ele conseguiu pagar pontualmente e sem problemas. Com os rendimentos do emprestimo anterior conseguiu construir uma casa embora seja de pau a pique , ela tem 2 quartos e uma varanda.Por isso agora quer tomar um outro emprestimo. Com os rendimentos do novo emprestimo, pensa em abrir uma sapataria em Chiquelene, que e uma zona semi-comercial, pois que ai muta gente podera apreciar os sapatos que ele fabrica e quica o numero de clientes aumente. Ele pensa expandir o seu negocio para uma outra zona no intuito de angariar mais clientes. para tal tera necessidade de contratar mais um empregado para o ajudar. Portanto a sua vida registou melhorias muito positivas.

loans.use: To buy more material to make shoes

loans.name: Fina Mario Luis

texts.pt:
Fina Mario Luis G. lives with her partner and two school-age children in the suburbs of Xai-Xai City, Mozambique. Fina's husband, currently unemployed, helps with the household expenses by doing odd jobs, which occasionally includes selling wood. Fina was encouraged to join the credit program by her neighbors, who, since joining, have been able to improve their lives. She has a small market in the neighborhood of Ndambine, where she sells basic food products to the community, including snacks to the local school's students. Fina will use her $425 loan to buy more products to sell at her market. She hopes to be able to build a good house for her family, one day.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva volunteer.

Fina e solteira. mas vive com um homem com quem tem 2 filhos. O marido de Fina nao estra empregado vive de pequenos expedientes para o sustento de sua familia e as vezes faz algum negocio de venda de madeira. Por isso Fina decidiu entrar para o programa de Credito. Este Emprestimo que vai tomar sera o primeiro. A motivacao para ela aderir ao programa e porque diz que as vizinhas estao a evoluir em sua vida e em conversa com elas soube que elas sao clientes do FDM. Ela tem uma baraca onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade e fornece lanches para a Escola existente na aldeia Ndambine-2000, local onde ela pratica o seu negocio. Ela vive com sua familia numa outra zona periferica da cidade de Xai-Xai. Os filhos do casal estao a estudar. Se tudo correr bem ela e o marido tem planos de construir uma habitacao condigna para eles.

loans.use: To buy more food products to sell at her market

loans.name: Kirinyabigo I(A) Group

texts.en:
Milly has a restaurant business. With the extra business profits, she intends to buy a plot of land and build a house. Harriet and Grace sell raw foods in the market and want to use the loan to expand the business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy food warmers.

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en: Tahir (his wife is pictured)  was born in 1956. His family lives in the Salyan region in Yenikand village. Tahir has 3 children. They have been in farming business for 17 years.  Now this family needs a loan of $1200 to buy vine props for improving their vineyard.

loans.use: To buy vine props

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Antonio L. is 67 years old, married and has three adult children, and one of his daughters works with him. Antonio works in media marketing, ranging from publicity and advertisements to professional service presentations, promotions, making Web sites, technical supports, etc. On top of this, he also runs a small business with 12 employees that does human resource consulting.

With the loan Antonio will purchase furniture for the office. He is in the green shirt in the photo and is standing with one of his employees in charge of commercials.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

El señor Antonio L. tiene 67 años, es casado, tiene tres hijos mayores de edad de los cuales una hija trabaja con él. Antonio se dedica al Marketing de Medios, como por ejemplo publicidad, anuncios comerciales, presentación de Servicios de profesionales, promociones, elaboración de páginas Web, soporte técnico, etc.

Además de eso tiene otra micro empresa que se dedica a la consultaría de Recursos Humanos donde da empleo a 12 personas.

El crédito que solicita lo invertirá en su publicitaria para la compra de muebles para la empresa. En la foto es el señor de remera verde que aparece junto con uno de sus empleados encargados de la edición de los comerciales.

loans.use: Purchase office furniture.

loans.name: Kirinyabigo I(B) Group

texts.en:
Racheal is 27 years old and married with four children. She makes and sells snacks for a living. She wants to use the extra business profits to begin a poultry business. Rose has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to expand business. Mariam offers tailoring services.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Kirinyabigo I(C) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Penina is married with five children. She has a poultry business. She wants to get the extra business profits to pay school fees for the children. Rosette and Suza are poultry farmers and want to use the loan to expand the business. Mary sells soft drinks.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed.

loans.name: Pheobe

texts.en: Pheobe (in the middle of the photograph) is a trained nurse/midwife who manages her own private facility in Siaya, Kenya.  She is a 65-year-old widow and a mother of 9 children. She trained as a nurse in 1967 and worked for the government for 25 years, until 1992, when she retired and opened her own private clinic. Pheobe's clinic offers a wide range of health services, including general curative, family planning, and maternal and child health services. Pheobe attributes her success to hard work, perseverance, and three previous microfinance loans from KMET. She now needs a loan of US$1,200 to be able to renovate her clinic.

loans.use: Renovation of a clinic

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Kisumu Medical & Education Trust (K-MET) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Liberato

texts.es:
Liberato has his own vehicle with which he provides public transport between the cities of El Alto and La Paz. He works as a chauffer. This business is the source of the income with which he supports his three children, two of whom attend a state university while one is still in a local school. His wife does domestic work out of their home. They live in the Ciudad Satélite zone of the city of El Alto.

The requested loan will be used to maintain his work vehicle; maintaining the vehicle will allow him to continue contributing economically to the family.

This is Liberato's second loan with IMPRO; his good history with the institution qualifies him for another loan. Liberato has been an IMPRO client since 2005.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Liberato tiene su movilidad con la que trabaja de transporte publico Inter ciudad El Alto – La Paz; él trabaja de chofer y esta actividad es su fuente de ingresos con los que cubre la manutención de sus tres hijos, dos de ellos están en la universidad estatal y uno en el colegio, la esposa realiza trabajos domésticos en el hogar; vive en la Zona Ciudad Satélite de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito solicitado será utilizado en el mantenimiento de su movilidad de trabajo para seguir contribuyendo económicamente con la familia.

Es el segundo crédito con IMPRO, el buen antecedente con la institución le faculta aprobarle otro préstamo. Liberato es cliente nuestro desde el año 2005.

loans.use: Maintain the vehicle he uses as a chauffer

loans.name: Sarina

texts.es:
Sarina sells food in a stand on the street. She sells roast suckling pig and roast chicken Thursdays and Sundays in the fair "16 de Julio"; the rest of the days of the week she tends to the kiosk where she sells hamburgers and salchipapas ( a popular fast food dish with sausage and french fries). These activities are the primary source of income with which she supports her two year old son. Her husband went to Argentina to work as a tailor. Sarina lives in the "16 de Julio " zone of the city of El Alto.

The loan will be used to build her inventory by purchasing raw materials (pork, chicken and ingredients). Preparing more food will allow her to generate more income for her family.

This is Sarina's first loan with IMPRO. The evaluation of her loan application has qualified her for the requested loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Sarina es vivandera (vende comida en un puesto en la calle), comercializa Lechón de Cerdo y Pollo los días jueves y domingos en la feria 16 de julio y los demás días atiende su quiosco donde comercializa hamburguesas y salchipapas, siendo estas actividades su principal fuente de ingreso con los que cubre la manutención de su pequeño hijo de 2 años de edad, el esposo se fue al Republica de Argentina como costurero; vive en la Zona 16 de Julio de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinara para incrementar su mercadería, compra de insumos (carne de cerdo, de pollo e ingredientes) y así generar mayores ingresos familiares.

Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo solicitado.

loans.use: Purchase of pork meat, chicken meat and other cooking ingredients.

loans.name: German

texts.es:
German works as a public employee filling the roles of messenger and file clerk. He earns a salary with which he supports himself and his eldery mother. He lives in the Río Seco zone of the city of El Alto.

The loan is necessary in order to buy doors and windows for his small family home; the purchase will improve the family's comfort.

This is German's first loan with IMPRO. The evalation carried out on his loan application has qualified him for approval of the requested loan. This loan falls under IMPRO's Social Housing program.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

German trabaja como empleado público desempeñando funciones de mensajero y auxiliar de archivos; percibe un sueldo con el que se mantiene él y su madre que es de la tercera edad; vive en la Zona de Rió Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito es requerido para comprar puertas y ventanas y concluir su pequeña vivienda familiar y contar con mayor comodidad de hábitat.

Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le faculta para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por el prestatario. Este crédito cae bajo nuestro programa de Vivienda social.

loans.use: Purchase of doors and windows for his home.

loans.name: Mujeres En Acción Group

texts.es:
This group was formed thanks to Maria Rumilda Gonzáles, who along with being the general coordinator of this committee is also the president of her neighborhood council in Villa Maravilla.

Rumilda and her neighbors approached Kiva partner Fundación Paraguaya and were informed of the group program for women entrepreneurs and that's how they got started. The women who form this group are dedicated to different activities, selling, among other things: soft drinks and juice, charcoal, traditional home-made meals, shampoos and lotions, lingerie and other clothing, cushions and pillows, and kiosk items. They also take care of their households, save, and do work to improve their neighborhoods. One of their great successes was getting the city to build a bridge and a retaining wall to channel the water that was passing in front of their homes.

They are requesting the loan to purchase various supplies for their businesses to sell, such as charcoal, milk, bread, meat, women's clothing, lotions, shampoo, etc.
