This group has been together for one year. Margret is 46 years old, married and has four children. Her husband heads a nursery school. Margret is a poultry farmer and also does some cultivation. She wants to use the extra profits to expand her business and improve her standard of living. Mary, B. and R. all have poultry businesses and want to use the loan to purchase more chicks. N. offers catering services and wants to use the loan to buy a refrigerator and purchase more furniture.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Kabawo I(B) Group

texts.en: This group has been together for one year. Margret is 46 years old and married with four children. The busband heads a nursery school. Margret is a poultry farmer and also does some little cultivation. She wants to use the extra profits to expand her business and improve her standards of living. Mary, B. and R. all have poultry businesses and want to use the loan to purchase more chicks. N. offers catering services and wants to use the loan to buy a fridge and purchase more furniture.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feeds.

loans.name: Thi Ha

texts.vi:
Mrs Hà is 25. She is a young lady but hard working and determined. She is married and has a young child. She does various tasks to make an income: work in the rice field, raises pigs, sells grocery. Her husband, Quân, is a skillful carpenter. Together, they are a hard working couple so their income is quite stable. She applies to Binh Minh cdc (SEDA) for a loan of 150 USD to have capital to invest and move forward.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hà, 25 tuổi, là một phụ nữ trẻ tuổi, chăm chỉ, đảm đang, tháo vát. Anh chị đã có hai con nhỏ. Hàng ngày, chị làm rất nhiều việc để tạo thu nhập cho gia đình như làm ruộng, nuôi lợn, đi chợ... Còn Anh Quân, chồng chị, làm nghề mộc rất khéo tay. Vợ chồng anh chị chăm chỉ nên thu nhập gia đình khá ổn định, Chị tham gia chương trình Tài chính vi mô Binhminh cdc với mức vốn vay 2006000đ để bổ sung vốn làm kinh tế.

loans.use: Raise pigs

loans.name: Kabawo I(C) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Betty is 40 years old, married and has five children. Her husband sells used clothes. Betty has a brick laying business. She usually earns 170, 000 shillings in profit each week. She wants to use the extra profit to reinvest in the brick business and also to improve the welfare of her family.

Aisha, Irene and Hadija all have poultry businesses and want to use the loan to construct more poultry houses.

Agnes sells soft drinks and intends to increase her stock with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Doeung

texts.en: Mrs. Doeung S., age 49, works with her husband growing rice crops, making on average around $2.50 each day in revenue. She has one child who works as a motor-taxi driver. She would like to request this loan of $800 in order to purchase pigs, poultry and feed to breed animals on her plot of land for additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase pigs, poultry and feed to breed animals on her plot of land for additional profit.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom S., age 46, works with her husband selling motorcycle spare parts to the people in their area, making around $7.50 profit. She has two children enrolled in school. She would like to request this loan of $1200 to purchase more motorcycle spare parts to expand her inventory and meet her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare parts to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(A) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Justine has a restaurant business. With the extra business profits she earns , she intends to pay school fees for her children and reinvest in the bsuiness.

Jane has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase her stock.

Christine has a beauty salon while Irene offers tailoring services.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Yung

texts.en: Mrs. Yung S., age, 36, works selling make-up products and perfume, earning around $5 each day of profit. Her husband works as a motorcycle driver making only $1.60 per day. They have five children: one is employed by a factory; one is a make-up artist; and the rest are enrolled in school. She would like to request this loan of $800 of to purchase more make-up products to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more make-up products to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(B) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Jane is a tailor. She intends to begin another business with her extra profits.

Joyce wants to use the loan to expand her catering business.

Fatuma sells charcoal.

Saidat sells and distributes water and wants to use the loan to buy a plastic water tank.

Aisha has a retail shop business and wants to increase her stock with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn C. T., age 34, works as a farmer growing vegetables, mainly peppers, making on average $10 each day. Her husband runs a motorcycle repair shop making on average $5 each day. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase more spare parts to supply her husband’s inventory to meet his growing clients’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase spare motorcycle parts to expand the repair business.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mrs. Chin S., age 37, is a widow and works as a traditional doctor making around $4 each day in revenue. She has two children, one who is a fisherman making $4 each day, and the other is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.use: To open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mrs. Chin S., age 37, is a widow and works as a traditional doctor making around $4 each day in revenue. She has two children, one who is a fisherman making $4 each day and one who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.use: To open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(C) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Saluma sells used clothing for a living. With the extra business profits she earns, she intends to start up another business.

Lucy has a poultry business and wants to use the loan to buy chicken feed.

Mary has a beauty salon and wants to buy a dryer with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea N., age 43, works as a broker buying plots of land and reselling them for a profit. She is a widow and has five children. One works as a fisherman, another one is a student, and the rest are married and live separately. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase another plot of land to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to sell for a profit.

loans.name: Thi Hue

texts.vi:
Mrs Huề is an active woman, hard working. She has 3 children, a happy family. Her husband, Thành, is a construction worker. Everyday, Mrs Huề would go to the neighboring hamlets to buy waste metal to resell to the recycling company. Her oldest daughter sells grocery to help out her family. Mrs Huề applies to Binh Minh cdc for a loan of 150 USD. She believes that by saving, she will be able to pay back the loan easily.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Huề là người phụ nữ đảm đang, năng động. Chị có một gia đình hạnh phúc với 3 con. Anh Thành, chồng chị, là một người thợ xây chăm chỉ. Hàng ngày, chị đi thu mua sắt vụn từ các thôn lân cận rồi mang về bán lại cho chủ hàng ở trong làng. Ngoài ra, cô con gái lớn của chị cũng dã đi bán hàng để phụ giúp bố mẹ, tạo thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị tham gia chương trình Tài chính vi mô Binhminh cdc với mức vốn 2006000đ để bổ sung vốn đi chợ. Chị tin rằng chỉ cần biết tiết kiệm chị cũng có thể hoàn trả vốn dễ dàng.

loans.use: Đi chợ mua hàng

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(D) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Roinah is 27 years old. She has a tailoring business. With the extra profits she makes, she intends to buy a piece of land and also reinvest in her business.

Jennifer has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy a steamer.

Agnes sells fruits and vegetables while Jane has a restaurant business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Mann

texts.en: Mrs. Mann M. Y., age 44, works selling various kinds of jewelry, making on average around $1.60 each day of profit. She started the business in 2005. Her husband is a blacksmith and makes on average around $3.30 each day. They have four children who are married. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase seeds to grow beans and yams to sell and generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds to grow beans and yams to sell and generate more income.

loans.name: Thi Thuy Ha

texts.vi:
Mrs Hà is 26, she has a young child. Her husband is in the military so he is often away from home. She stays home to take care of her child. She also raises egg laying chickens. Her family income is stable. Everyday she sells the chicken eggs so it would provide her a steady cash flow. She has never borrowed money before because she found it to be a complicated process. But now she applies to SEDA for a loan to buy chicken feed and vet medication.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hà năm nay 26 tuổi, chị có một con nhỏ. Chồng chị làm trong quân đội nên ít khi về nhà. Một mình chị ở nhà chăm con và chăn nuôi gà đẻ trứng. Thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng khá ổn định, ngày nào cũng có nguồn thu nhập từ việc bán trứng. Chị chưa vay vốn ở tổ chức chính thức nào vì theo chị, thủ tục cũng khá rườm rà và phức tạp. Tuy nhiên, lần này, chị làm tham gia vay vốn trả dần để mua cám chăn nuôi và một số thuốc thú y khác, như vậy, chị tiết kiệm được tốt hơn.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(E) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Maimuna is a 34 year old widow with six children. Four of the children go to school. She sells used clothes for a living. She earns about 70,000 shillings in profits each week. With extra business profits, Maimuna intends to pay school fees for her children and also start a poultry business. Madina sells new clothes and wants to increase her stock with the loan. Eva has a charcoal selling business while Betty runs a retail shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to increase her stock of clothing

loans.name: Kabawo Ii(E) Group

texts.en: This group has been together for one year. Maimuna is a 34 year old widow with six children. Four of the children go to school. She sells used clothes for a living. She earns about shs 70.000 in profits each week. With the extra business profis, Maimuna intends to  pay school fees for the children and also start a poultry business.Madina sells new clothes and wants to increase stock with the loan. Eva has a charcoal selling business while Betty runs a retail shop.

texts.en:
Hadija is 30 years old, married and has five children. She has a retail shop business.

Seh wants to use extra business profits to pay school fees for the children.

Maria offers tailoring services and wants to use the loan to buy another sewing machine.

Chrisitne sells used clothes and wants to increase her stock with the loan.

Prossy has a restaurant business and intends to use the loan to purchase more furniture.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.name: Nalukolongo 1(A) Group

texts.en: Sharifah is 32 years old and married with four children. She sells raw foods in the market. With the extra business profits, she intends to build a residential house and also start a cultivation business. Caroline and Joyce both have retail shop businesses and intend to use the loan to increase stock. Ruth makes and sells candles and wants to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the banana business

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea N., age 58, is a housewife. Her husband works as a farmer growing rice and vegetables, making on average around $1.50 each day. She has seven children. Two of them are employed by a garment factory, three are married and live separately, and the rest are unemployed. She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase a large quantity of cashew nuts from growers and resell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of cashew nuts from growers and resell them for a profit.

loans.name: Nalukolongo 1(B) Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Hadijah is 32 years old and married with four children. She has a poultry business. With the extra business profits, she intends to pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: To expand the poultry business

loans.name: Nalukolongo 1(C) Group

texts.en: Majorine is 28 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. She sells raw foods in the market. Majorine wants to use the extra business profits to re-invest and expand her food business. Rose wants to use the loan to purchase more charcoal for sale. Goretti has a retail shop and wants to increase stock with the loan. Aisha works in a hotel while Annet has a cosmetic shop.

loans.use: To purchase more foods for sale

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Mrs. Lun H., aged 59, is a housewife. Her husband works as a farmer growing rice and various kinds of vegetables, earning only $1 each day. She has two children who are married, and one of her children’s family lives with them. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase more rice seeds and yams to expand her crops and raise her income.

loans.use: To purchase more rice seed and yams to expand her crops.

loans.name: Pron

texts.en: Mrs. Pron N., 44, is a mother of seven children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works with her husband, as brokers purchasing coconuts, bananas, and pigs to resell for a profit, earning collectively a profit of around $4 each day. This couple has been in this business since 1996. Three of their children are employed by a garment factory, two are married, and the rest are too young to attend school. Mrs. Pron N. hopes to use this loan to expand her business by purchasing more pigs and fruits.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more pigs and fruits.

loans.name: Nalukolongo 1(D) Group

texts.en: Jane is 37 years old and married with four children. Her husband is an herbalist. Jane sells soft drinks for a living. She usually earns 50.000 in profits weekly. She wants to use the extra profits to open up a beverage shop. Jariah sells charcoal and wants to use the loan to expand business. Sarah is a poultry farmer while Josephine has a retail shop business.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Nalukolongo 2(A) Group

texts.en: Shakira is 28 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a mechanic. Shakira has a beauty salon business and usually earns about shs 70,000 in profits each week. She wants to use the extra business profits to pay school fees for the children and also increase salon business. Hadijah has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase stock. Nulu sells used clothes while Joyce sells raw foods in the market.

loans.use: To buy a salon steamer

loans.name: Nalukolongo 2(A) Group

texts.en: Shakira is 28 years old and married with three children. The husband is a mechanic. Shakira has a beauy salon business and usally earns about shs 70,000 in profits each week. She wants to use the extra business profits topay school fees for the children and also add in salon business. Hadijah has a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase stock. Nulu sells used clothes while Joyce sellls raw foods in the market.

loans.use: To buy a salon steamer

loans.name: Nalukolongo 2(B) Group

texts.en: Zaria is 40 years old and married with two children. She sells new clothes/ garments. With the extra business profits, she intends to pay school fees for the children and solve her other problems. Margret, Annet and Madina all sell used clothes and want to use the loan to expand business. Harriet is a bar and restaurant attendant while Florence sells furniture for a living.

loans.use: To expand clothes selling business

texts.en: Josephine has a retail shop business. She intends to use the extra business profits to cater to the family and also open up an account and save some. Nakato sells charcoal and wants to use the loan to expand business. Safinah sells new clothes and wants to use the loan to add stock.

loans.use: To increase stock in the shop

loans.name: Wambizzi A Group

texts.en: Josephine has a retail shop business. She intends to use the extra business profits to cater for the family and also open up an account and save some. Nakato sells charcol and wants to use the loan to expand business. Safinah sells new clothes and wants to use the loan to add in stock.

loans.use: To increase stock in the shop.

texts.en:
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rose is a 49 year old widow with nine children. She sells charcoal for a living. Rose usually earns shs 50.000 in profits each week. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house for the children and also re-invest in the charcoal business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Wambizzi C Group

texts.en: Rebecca is 25 years old and married with two children. She offers tailoring services.  Rebecca usually earns UGX 60,000 in profits each week. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house and also pay school fees for herchildren. Robina wants to use the loan to expand her brick laying business. Prossy and Eva have retail shop businesses while Resty sells fish for a living.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena operates a small business selling baby clothes and supplies in Nikolaev, Ukraine. She has an attractively arranged little outdoor kiosk at the Ekur market in Nikolaev where she carries all sorts of necessary items for new mothers. Elena has been in business for about six years and has developed a stable, profitable enterprise based on products that are always in demand. Her business has become the main source of income for her and her husband, Anotolyi. In a typical month she makes around $1300 in profit.

Elena’s business is growing. She has requested a loan of $1200 to increase her working capital and help boost the further development of her business.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Ramzan's Group

texts.en:
"I live in a small town: Chichawatni, Pakistan. One of my sons trades livestock. He earns well and currently, he needs a loan to buy a few additional sheep. He is the only breadwinner of our family.

My group members are: Sakina B. who will invest the loan in their fruit business; Razia B. who also needs loan for their fruit business; Akhteri B. will use the loan in their family’s cattle trading business; and Shamim B. who needs a loan for their rickshaw. All of us are mutually responsible for each other’s loans."

loans.use: Buy a few sheep

loans.name: Azad

texts.en:
Mr. Azad F. is a low-income person. He is 21, married with two children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region. Azad rents a barber's together with his father (who is pictured). They serve clients and at the end of each month they pay the landlord for the rent.

There is a school season coming up and as a rule all schoolchildren cut their hair before going to school. Azad's barber's shop isn't in good condition and needs to be renovated immediately. Azad has applied for $500 to Normicro Saatli branch. After getting the loan and renovating the shop he plans to get more customers and increase his daily income.

loans.use: For renovations

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
"I am Nazira B. from a small town: Chichawatni, Pakistan. This is my birth town. I am married and the mother of six: four boys and two girls. My husband operates a cotton goods store and wants to expand it. Thanks be to God, our business generates decent profits.

I am requesting loans for my group members as well. Zohra B. requires a loan for her son who is a tailor. Talat B.’s husband sells fruit. Sarweri B. sells milk. Razia S. wants a loan for her son who is a plumber."

loans.use: Expand cotton goods store

loans.name: Masanda C(I) Group

texts.en: Margret is a 40 year old widow with four children. She has a charcoal selling business. With the extra business profits, she intends to construct a residential house. Rehema offers tailoring services and wants to use the loan to buy a sewing machine. Mary sells firewood and wants to use the loan to expand business. Florence sells fish while Juliet owns a beauty salon.

loans.use: To add in charcoal business

loans.name: Masanda C(Ii) Group

texts.en: Madalena is divorced with five children. She sells charcoal for a living. She intends to use the extra business profits to pay school fees for the children. Jane sells handbags and wants to use the loan to expand profits. Immaculate sells airtime cards and wants to re-invest in the business with the loan. Rebecca has a piggery business while Faith is a poultry farmer.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
"I have been living in a small town called Chichawatni since I got married 12 years ago. I have four kids: two girls and two boys. Except my youngest son, all our kids attend school. I stitch clothes at my home to supplement my husband’s income. My husband is a rickshaw driver; he bought the rickshaw on installments. Now, we need to pay off the few remaining installments of our rickshaw for which we require a loan.

I would to like to borrow in a group with a few neighboring women. Parween B. needs a loan to buy her son a machine required in shoe manufacturing. Basheera R. will invest her loan in their family’s sanitary store. Basheera B. needs a loan to buy a rickshaw for her son. Tasmiah B.’s son is a barber."

loans.use: Pay off remaining installments on our rickshaw

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina is 42-year-old mother of four who is married to Flaminio G., an electrician. Both she and her husband have worked countless hours to buy the house which they live in. This house is in the city of San Lorenzo, where Agustina works in a general store she opened 10 years ago.

Now that two of her older children are living on their own, Agustina has been able to save some money and wants to expand her business. Her plan is to build a store of her own and increase it from a general store to a little supermarket. Today, Agustina is asking for a loan to increase the goods sold in her store to include food like flour, rice and sugar, along with some simple types of clothing. With this loan, she will be able to accelerate the process of opening a supermarket of her own.

loans.use: To buy merchandise and products for a general store, including flour, oil, rice, pasta, sugar and clothes such as shorts, blouses, and t-shirts.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
"I am Razia S.. I live in a small town called Chichawatni in Pakistan with my family. I am the mother of seven. I am borrowing for the first time from Asasah, a microfinance institution. My husband is a plumber and needs a loan to buy some tools and other items such as pipes etc.

Hassan B. needs a loan to buy cloth for their cloth sales business. Asifa B. plans to start a grocery store. Nusrat B.’s husband sells fruit on a cart. I completely trust these women."

loans.use: Buy some plumbing tools and other items for our businesses

loans.name: Masanda C(Iii) Group

texts.en: Halima is 39 years old and married with four children. All the children go to school. Her husband is an exporter. She has a charcoal selling business. She usually earns shs 15.000 in profits weekly. With the extra business profits, Halima intends to pay school fees for the children and also meet their other requirements. Maria has a retail shop business and wants to use the loan to increase stock. Margret sells used clothes while Harriet works in a hotel.

loans.use: To add in charcoal business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Cerfila

texts.en:
Cerfila V. is a 67-year-old mother and wife who makes a living selling refreshments. Twenty years ago she had a convenience store that didn’t have much success, so decided to close it and go into this line of work.

Her work selling refreshments makes great deal of profit because demand for her goods is strong. Now that she has had success in this line of work, she would like to expand her product line to include a greater variety of drinks and possibly snacks as well. With this loan she will first invest in new kinds of drinks, and afterwards explore the possibility of adding small snacks.

loans.use: To buy general refreshments such as soda, juice, beer, wine and water.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena A. has a small business selling charcoal in the city of San Lorenzo. She has three children and a husband who once worked in construction. But when he realized how profitable his wife’s company was, he left construction and went into business with her. Now they work together selling bags of charcoal to local businesses.

Elena has applied for a loan to buy more heir merchandise to sell. She hopes to continue to increase the size of their business so that she can afford to keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Ali

texts.ru:
Ali is a resident of Saalti region. He is 44 and married with two children. Ali has been in business for 10 years and has a small food store, where his wife also helps him. Recently, business has been good. He needs to increase his assortment of goods, but lacks the working capital to do so. For this reason, he has applied to the Saalti branch of Normicro for a loan of $1000, to be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Али является жителем Саатлинского района. Ему 44 года, женат, имеет 2 детей. Али занимается бизнесом уже 10 лет. У него неболшой продуктовый магазин. В торговле ему помогает жена. В последнее время торговля идет хорошо. Ему необходимо расширить ассортимент товаров, но весь его каритал вложен в оборот. По этой причине он обратился в Саатлинский филиал Нормикро для получения кредита в сумме 1000 USD на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: to buy new varieties

loans.name: Evarista

texts.en:
With the help of her husband, Evarista runs a small convenience store out of her house. She has two teenagers who are currently in school. Her business has grown a little at a time and now, after 12 years, it has become quite profitable.

Financial support from Fundación Paraguaya helped Evarista start her business, and she is now applying for a new loan to help her company grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as cleaning products, sugar, meat, dairy, etc. for a small business

loans.name: Masanda D(I) Group

texts.en: Imelda is 30 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a driver. Imelda has a piggery business and earns about shs 50.000 in profits each week. Imelda wants to use the extra business profits to pay school fees for the children. Gladys bakes and sells bread for a living and wants to use the loan to purchase more baking ingredients. Margret and Faith both have poultry businesses and want to purchase poultry feeds. Mariam has a stone quarrying business.

loans.use: To buy more piglets

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose G. is married and has three children in elementary school. For the last 17 years, he has been in the business of making sports uniforms for businesses and schools. His company has expanded since it began, and now he works with two employees.

Jose’s business is in a lucrative part in the city of San Lorenzo, where schools, businesses and club sports always need uniforms. With this loan, he plans to buy the material and other accessories he needs to make more uniforms.

loans.use: To buy clothing and accessories to sell in his store.

loans.name: Masanda D(Ii) Group

texts.en: Edith is 23 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a mechanic. She sells used clothes for a living. Edith wants to use the extra business profits to re-invest in her clothes business. Agnes has a stone quarry business, while Christine is a poultry farmer.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase 60 sportswear sets

loans.name: Kabojja B1(A) Group

texts.en: Margret is 48 years old and married with six children. Her husband sells cereals. Margret has a retail shop business. She wants to use the extra profits to provide a good quality education for her children. Ritah sells clothes and wants to expand business with the loan. Mariam has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy a hair steamer. Agnes sells raw foods in the market while Goretti is a poultry farmer.

loans.use: To increase stock in the shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rahila

texts.ru:
Rahila lives in Saalti with her husband and 10 children. She is 57 years old and has been in business for 25 years. Her husband (shown in the photo) and oldest son help her with her business. They own a veterinary drugstore and need to obtain new supplies of medicine. Rahila has applied to the Saalti branch of Normicro for a loan of $1000, to be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Рахиля живет в городе Саатлы вместе со своей семьей - мужем и 10 детьми. Ей 57 лет. Бизнесом она занимается вот уже 25 лет. В этом ей помогает муж (он на фото) и старший сын.Они содержат ветеренарную аптеку.В данный момент им нужно приобрести новые препараты. И Рахиля обратилась в Саатлинский филиал Нормикро для получения кредита в сумме 1000 USD на 12 месяцев

loans.use: To buy new medicines

loans.name: Kabojja B1(B) Group

texts.en: Ephrance has a market stall and sells raw foods like matooke, cassava and sweet potatoes. She intends to use the extra business profits to complete her rental houses that are under construction. Justine and Mayimuna both sell used clothes for a living and want to increase stock with the loan. Nulu has a bar business.

loans.use: To purchase more foods for sale.

loans.name: Famil

texts.en:
Mr. Famil G. is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 32 and lives together with his people in Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region.

Famil rents a barber's. He serves clients and at the end of each month pays for the rent. The business is going well, but Famil's barber shop isn't in good condition and needs to be renovated immediately. Otherwise Famil could incur the risk of losing clients. This winter he applied for $500 to Normicro Saatli branch.

After getting the loan and renovating the shop he plans to collect more customers and increase his daily income.

loans.use: For renovations

loans.name: Kabojja B1(C) Group

texts.en: Latifah is 32 years old and married with one child. Her husband is a driver. She sells charcoal for a living. Latifah wants to use the extra profits to start up a poultry business. Robinah and Teddy both have retail shop businesses and want to use the loan to increase stock. Sarah sells crafts and wants expand the business with the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for sale and increase stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tahir

texts.ru:
Tahir is 43 years old and married with three children. He has been working as a barber for 30 years. Not long ago he acquired his own barbershop. Since he spent all his savings buying the shop, Tahir has applied to the Saalti branch of Normicro for a loan of $500, to be repaid over 12 months. He needs the money to buy new furniture.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Тахиру 43 года, женат, имеет 3 детей. Вот уже 30 лет работает парикмахером. Недавно он приобрел салон. Так как все свои сбережения он вложил в покупку салона Тахир обратился в Саатлинский филиал для получения кредита в сумме 500 USD на 12 месяцев. Эта сумма нужна ему на покупку новой мебели.

loans.use: To buy new furniture

loans.name: Mujeres Emprenadoras Group

texts.en:
This committee Women Entrepreneurs of the Mbayue neighborhood was formed by a member who previously belonged to a different group of businesswomen. As an entrepreneur, she saw the need for a new support group for women, so she founded one, holding meetings in her own house. Soon her small group grew into a group of seventeen.

Together they are asking for a loan to help increase the size of their businesses. Only a small amount of capital is needed by these women to begin to earn more profits. The loan will be used to buy merchandise for jewelry stores, washrooms, general stores and convenience stores.

loans.use: To buy materials to sell, including clothes, sheets, towels, shoes, fruits, vegetables, tennis shoes, snacks, meat, cheese and perfumes.

loans.name: Kabojja B1(D) Group

texts.en: N. is 30 years old and married with five children. She has a retail shop business. With the extra business profits, she intends to build rental houses. Josephine and Hadijah both sell used clothes and want to increase stock with the loan. Ruth has a beauty salon while Sarah sells raw foods in the market.

loans.use: To increase stock in the shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Elva

texts.en:
Elva A. makes ropes, speacializing in clothes lines, in the city of Mariano R. Alonso. This has been her business and her main source of income for eleven years. She sells her rope not only to businesses in her hometown, but to other stores large cities throughout Paraguay. Hardware stores and general stores in the cities of Ciudad del Este, Villarrica, Coronel Oviedo, Caaguazú, and Encarnación all sell ropes made by Elva A..

She began the business with a small amount of capital, and through her great business sense and exceptional product, her company has grown. It provides a good income for Elva, her husband and two children. It has also provided her two children the opportunity to attend school.

In order to satisfy her faithful customers, Elva is asking for a loan in order to buy the rope material. She hopes that news of his business will continue to travel throughout Paraguay and that she will continue to see and increase in business and profits.

loans.use: To buy material to make ropes and cords.

loans.name: Tamilla

texts.en:
Tamilla is a low-income vulnerable woman. She is 53, married with two children and lives in Saatli town in Azerbaijan in Caucasus region. She has some goods to sell and runs business from the window of her house.

The capital she has leaves much to be desired. To increase her monthly turnover, Tamilla has to make investments. This winter she applied for $500 to Normicro, a KIVA partner, to expand her business.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Jorge

texts.en:
Jorge M. is happily married with two children--one lives at home and attends grade school while the other is an adult living in Argentina. He and his family live in San Lorenzo where he has a hardware store.

Ten years ago, Jorge applied for a loan from Fundación Paraguaya and used it to establish this business, which has become quite popular. His dream is for his son to graduate from college and possibly go into business as well. Jorge is asking for a loan to buy tools to stock his hardware store and increase sales.

loans.use: To buy paint, bricks, cement and other construction materials.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisa D. is a working mother with three children . Her two older children live away from home, but she still cares for her youngest child, who is attending college.

Since 2000, Francisa has worked in a store while her husband works as a sugar cane farmer. Thanks to the investment of some of her husband’s savings, she was able to open this store in the lower level of their home. She appreciates the sacrifices her husband has made to make her business possible.

In addition to her husband’s savings, Francisca took out a loan with the Fundación Paraguaya in 2006. She is very grateful for this support. She wants to continue expanding her business and is asking for a new loan to purchase food items, such as sugar, rice and pasta, to sell.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, pasta, oil, milk and other food items to sell.

loans.name: Sadig

texts.en:
Mr. Sadig is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 38, married with five children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Sadig together with his wife (she is pictured) has a herd of milk cows and sells 100 liters of milk a day to the local milk processing shop and to the supermarket. The trade is good and Sadig can see that he could sell more milk. This requires more cattle in the herd. Sadig decided to buy two calves to breed and hence to increase monthly turnover.

He has applied for a $700 loan to Normicro Saatli branch for the purpose to buy two cows and increase number of cattle in his herd.

loans.use: To buy two milk cows

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita F. is a young mother with three children in elementary school. Her husband makes shoes for a living, and she owns a neighborhood clothing store. Margarita began her working life as a clerk in a book store, but opened her own business after managing to save some capital from that job.

Margarita saw the need for a good clothing store in her neighborhood and used the small amount of money she set adise to set one up in her own house. After she was established there and earning money, she moved the store into a rented location in the nearby shopping center. Margarita is asking for a loan to help purchase more clothing for her store, including shirts, blouses, jeans and skirts.

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as shirts, shoes, skirts, blouses, pants and jeans.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Agustin V. worked as a driver for an electronic shop for two years before deciding that he wanted to form his own small business. He began by buying small electric home products, rope and other merchandise to sell door to door.

With a loan issued to him by Fundación Paraguaya, he was able to buy a motorcycle and transport goods with much more ease. Having a mode of transportation opened up many more possibilities for the expansion of his business. While he was away on deliveries his wife stayed home to take care of their two children.

Today his dream is to save enough money to open his own store in his house. As a traveling salesman, he is away from home a lot and would like to be around his children more of the time. However, he knows that his income is the only way to give his children the opportunity to attend school, an experience he wishes he had as a child.

loans.use: To buy fans, grills, sheets, mosquito nets, and jeans.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris Menyah is a hairdresser who has her own salon. She is married to a transport driver and has a child who is 7 years old. Doris wants to support her husband with the family finances since his daily income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family. She wants to improve upon her working environment to attract more customers to her salon.

Doris is asking for $600 as an additional fund to enable her to change the outlook of the salon and buy some new hair dryers.

loans.use: To change the look of the salon and buy new hair dryers.

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en:
53-year-old Vagif lives with his family including three children in Saatli town of Azerbaijan, which is situated in Caucasus region. Vagif is the only breadwinner for his family. His family’s living conditions are not good enough because the family income is rather limited.

Vagif began his business 15 years ago. Because he did not have sufficient financial resources, he couldn’t develop his business well enough in the beginning. With this small business and only $200 in working capital, he could hardly earn enough money to meet his family's food and important consumption needs, but after awhile he made important steps in his business and increased the area of his trading.

Now, he wants to borrow $500 in order to further develop his business, and therefore to improve his family’s living conditions and obtain some funds for the education of his children.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca N. prepares a special type of doughnut which is commonly eaten by workers who might be too busy to take their breakfast in their homes. Rebeccais divorced and has a child who is 12 years old. She wants to improve upon her working conditions so as to attract more customers.

Rebecca is asking for $400 to enable her to buy a Beff (doughnut) stand which will make her business very attractive and also improve her sales.

loans.use: To buy a doughnut stand to improve her sales.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina D. trades in cosmetics, and artificial hair. She is a divorcee with two children, ages 22 and 18. She wants to increase her sales as well as her income.

She is asking for $500 as additional capital to buy more goods (artificial hair, cosmetics and others) to meet the needs of her increasing customers.

loans.use: To buy more goods (artificial hair, cosmetics) to meet the needs of her increasing clientele.

loans.name: Cristo Rey Group

texts.en:
The fifteen women you see here have formed a support group and come together once a week to discuss their various businesses. They have taken the name of “Cristo Rey,” and work hard in their various businesses to support their families. Some of them bring their children to meetings while others come alone. They all work together, supporting one another in pursuit of increased business profits.

Some women sell clothes, others make clothes. They sell food and household goods and provide various services. They are asking for a loan to keep their businesses growing and to increase their profits .

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables, eggs, oil, plastic goods, clothes, and other items.

loans.name: Mercedes De Fatima

texts.es:
Senora Mercedes started her small business because she needed to help cover her household costs. Her husband was not earning enough to take care of the house and the children's education. She began 13 years ago in the market at the Leon station, and has generated income to take care of her family and grow the business.

It's important to note that Mercedes is a very hardworker, opening her business very early in the morning every day to serve her loyal customers. For 3 years now she has been working with loans from Ceprodel, which have helped her invest in her business. So far she has received and repaid 10 loans.

La pulpería de la señora Mercedes nace a partir de la necesidad de mantener su hogar debido a que su esposo no obtenía suficientes ingresos para mantener a sus dos hijos en edad escolar. El negocio nace desde hace 13 años en el mercado la Estación de la ciudad de León y hoy en día ha generado ganancias que le han servido para mantener su hogar y su negocio.

Algo muy importante de destacar es que la señora Mercedes es muy esforzada debido a que todos los días desde muy tempranas horas abre las puertas de su negocio para esperar a sus fieles clientes. Desde hace 3 años ha obtenido créditos en Ceprodel que según cuenta le han beneficiado para sacar adelante su negocio e invertir en la infraestructura de su local que es su meta. Su record es de 10 créditos con Ceprodel.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MERCHANDISE FOR HER SMALL GENERAL STORE WHICH SHE RUNS FROM A STAND IN THE STATION OF LEON.

loans.name: Jerónima Esperanza

texts.es:
Jeronima P. has beeen selling a wide assortment of fruits and vegetables from her stand in the Leon station market for 50 long years. Before she began this work, she was a housewife, but she realized the difficulty of covering the household costs and decided to use her small savings to purchase fruits and vegetables to later sell.

It is clear that she needs to invest in the infrastructure of her stand. The roof is in poor condition and when it rains her merchandise gets soaked. Senora P. has been working with loans from Ceprodel to stock her business in larger quantities. Her primary goal is to be able to construct her own stand so she will be able to offer better service to all of her customers. She has received 5 loaons so far with Ceprodel.

Yuca, pipianes, repollos, hierba buena, naranjas agrias, etc. son los productos que muy esforzadamente vende la señora Jeronima P. en el mercado la Estación en León desde hace 50 largos años. Antes de dedicarse a esta actividad su labor era desempeñarse como ama de casa, pero al contemplar que difícilmente cubría los gastos de su hogar decide invertir su poco capital en la compra de verduras para luego comercializarlas.

No podemos pasar por alto que le es de mucha utilidad invertir en la infraestructura de su negocio ya que actualmente su techo y pared están en malas condiciones por lo que en momentos de lluvia sus productos se mojan.

Muy sabiamente, la señora P. ha realizado créditos en Ceprodel para surtir su negocio con mayores volúmenes de productos de verduras, su mayor anhelo es construir su propio tramo para brindar un mejor servicio a todos sus clientes. Su record es de 5 créditos con ceprodel.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO INVEST IN THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF HER SMALL MARKET STAND.  THE ROOF IS IN BAD CONDITION AND HER MERCHANDISE IS GETTING SOAKED WHEN IT RAINS.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria G. is a hardworking woman who for 25 years has been selling fruits and vegetables in the Leon station market. She is considered a happy and humble woman, who began her business with a small amount of money which she'd saved over a long time.

Gloria is the single mother of 3 children, and needs to provide for their care and education. Her main goal is to enable her children to prepare for professional careers, so that they do not suffer as she has suffered from working so hard from such a young age.

3 years ago, Gloria received help from Ceprodel, using the loans to pruchase more products to sell and fix up her market stand. She has received and repaid 19 loans so far.

Gloria G. es una dama muy trabajadora que desde hace 25 largos años se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras de todo tipo en el mercado la Estación en León. Se caracteriza por ser una dama muy alegre y humilde. Su negocio lo comenzó con un capital propio de C$ 500 obtenidos por medio de sus ahorros propios de largo tiempo.

Actualmente es madre soltera de tres hijos los cuales tiene el deber de brindarles educación ya que son menores de edad. Su mayor anhelo es que sus hijos se preparen para poder ser profesionales y no sufrir como ella considera que sufrió desde muy joven con trabajos muy pesados.

Desde hace tres años, la señora Gloria se ha apoyado de Ceprodel, obteniendo préstamos que los ha invertido directamente en su negocio para la compra de sus productos y la remodelación de su local en el mercado la Estación. Actualmente su record crediticio es de 19 créditos con Ceprodel.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE FRUITS AND VEGETABLES FOR HER SMALL BUSINESS IN THE CENTRAL MARKET.

loans.name: Marta Lorena

texts.es:
Marta P. is a married mother of two. Twelve years ago she began selling vegetables in the ‘La Estación de León’ marketplace distinguishing herself as a being happy and very attentive to her customers.

She characterizes herself as being a hard worker and is one of the more popular vendors in the marketplace. These two qualities have allowed her to be known as a responsible person and she takes great job in what she does.

For a long time now, she has struggled to make a better her family’s economic situation and to provide what education she can. Unfortunately, they are unable to attend school because of their family’s economic hardship and because they must help their mother run the business. Nevertheless, Marta aspires to provide her children with formal educational opportunities. For this reason, she has requested loans from Ceprodel to invest in her business and thus increase the family’s income to pay for her children’s education. (She currently has a credit record of 20 credits)

:

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Marta P. es madre casada y con dos hijos a su cargo. Desde hace 12 años inició a vender verduras en el mercado La Estación de León, destacándose principalmente por ser una dama muy alegre y atenta con los clientes.

Se caracteriza por ser una mujer muy trabajadora, ya que es una de las mas conocidas en el mercado, esto la ha llevado a que sea muy responsable en el local y por tal razón se siente orgullosa de laborar en este negocio.

Por mucho tiempo atrás ha venido luchando por mejorar su situación económica y brindarles educación a sus dos pequeños ya que lamentablemente ellos no estudian primeramente por su difícil situación económica y segundo porque apoyan a su madre en el trabajo diario en el mercado. Sin embargo, a pesar de esta situación, la señora Marta anhela que sus hijos estudien y por tal razón ha iniciado a solicitar préstamos en Ceprodel para invertir en el negocio y así obtener mayores utilidades para cubrir los estudios de sus hijos.(Actualmente su record crediticio es de 20 créditos)

loans.use:
Purchase of vegetables

Compra de las verduras

loans.name: Fredy

texts.en:
Fredy Mendoza is a 27 year old father of two children who lives in a populated neighborhood in the town of Luque.  As a single father, Fredy has been dedicated to recycling all types of paper and cardboard and selling them to local businesses.

Fredy has been in business for  five years now and the business supports his family.  He is applying for a loan in order to buy a great quantity of papers which will increase the quantity of clients and his sales.

loans.use: To buy paper and cardboard.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Mrs. Cecilia V. is married and has 2 children. She lives in the Villa Reconciliación de Managua neighborhood. She works at the industrial zone but also sells milk curd and cream out of her home. Mrs. V.' husband is retired and receives a monthly pension from the Social Security. He helps her sell the cream and curd while she is at work.

Thanks to these three sources of income they have been able to get ahead and to start building their home. The loan will be used to raise one of the concrete walls of the house, which currently is made of sheets of zinc roofing material and causes them a lot of problems.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Cecilia es casada y tiene 2 hijos. Habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de Managua. Trabaja en una zona industrial, pero también tiene un negocio de venta de cuajada y crema en su casa de Habitación. El esposo de doña Cecilia está ya junilado y recibe una pensión mensual del Seguro Social, y es él quien le ayuda con las ventas del negocio mientras ella trabaja. Con estos tres ingresos de la familia es cómo han podido salir adelante y han ido construyendo su casa, el préstamo lo usarán para levantar una de las paredes de su vivenda de concreto, que actualmente es de zinc y conlleva muchas dificultades para ellos.

loans.use: To raise one of the concrete walls of their home

loans.name: Olinda

texts.es:
Ms. Olinda is a member of the cummunal bank Mujeres Luchadoras de Yungay, she earns a living selling groceries. Her business is located at the district market in the Yungay province.

With the loan of $275.00 (S/800.00 soles), which will be paid off in 6 installments, she will purchase 3 sacks of rice and 3 sacks of sugar for her business.

Ms. Olinda is 42 years old, lives with her partner and has 3 underage children. She is able to provide an education for her children with the earnings from her business.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Olinda pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Luchadoras de Yungay, su actividad es la venta de abarrotes y su negocio está ubicado en el campo ferial del distrito y provincia de Yungay.

Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00 soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 3 sacos de arroz y 3 sacos de azúcar para implementar su negocio.

Ella tiene 42 años, es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos menores de edad; con los ingresos que genera su negocio educa a sus hijos.

loans.use: To purchase rice and sugar wholesale

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Maria Auxiliadora is a single mother of two children, a 16 year old boy and a 6 year old girl. They live in the Villa Venezuela neighborhood. Ms. Maria is a small business owner. She runs a small general store out of her home, where she sells a variety of products used in everyday life to neighbors and area residents.

Since this is her family's only source of income, she needs to work very hard to earn enough money to support her family. She needs the loan to purchase more merchandise for her store and to expand the variety of products she offers. This will allow her to increase her earnings to support her two children.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Maria Auxiliadora es madre soltera de 2 hijos, un varón de 16 años y una niña de 6 años, habitan en el barrio Villa Venezuela. Doña Maria es una pequeña comerciante que como negocio posee una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación, donde atende diariamente a varios vecinos del lugar que buscan los productos de consumo básicos del hogar.

Siendo el único ingreso de su familia, necesita poner mucho empeño para generar los ingresos suficientes para sostener a su familia. Requiere el crédito para invertir en variedad de productos y así expandir su mercadería y al mismo tiempo el ingreso necesario para la manutención de sus dos pequeños.

loans.use: To purchase assorted merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Armando De Jesús

texts.es:
Mr. Armando N. has worked selling products of all kinds (a general store) for more than three years. He began this activity due to the fact that the small business in his home was not resulting in enough income. His income decreased more each day and for that reason, he moved to the Terminal market in Leon, which is where he is currently located.

Currently his biggest dream is to improve the physical condition of his business since it is in bad conditions and for that reason, he needs to invest in the infrastructure and continue with his business which has permitted him to have daily sustenance for his family.

He is asking for a loan from CEPRODEL, who will extend a friendly hand to him and finance his business. He currently has a record of 15 credits.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Conover, Kiva.org volunteer.

El señor Armando N. se dedica a la actividad de venta de productos de toda índole (pulpería ) desde hace mas de tres años e inicia esta actividad por iniciativa de que el pequeño negocio que atendía en su casa no le resultaba ya que los ingresos disminuían cada día mas y por tal razón se traslada al mercado la Terminal de León que es el local donde actualmente esta ubicado.

Actualmente su mayor sueño es mejorar las condiciones de su local ya que están en malas condiciones y por tal razón necesita invertir en su infraestructura y seguir en su negocio que le ha permitido el obtener el sustento diario de su familia. Es así que solicita préstamo a CEPRODEL quien le extiende su mano amiga y le financia para su negocio. Actualmente tiene un record de 15 créditos.

loans.use: Improve locale of a general store

loans.name: Eudomia

texts.es:
Making bread, snacks, cookies and empanadas is the business that Ms. Eudoxia O. does in her own bakery in the outskirts of the Terminal market in the department of Leon.

She has been doing this for 15 years. Due to the fact that the income from her life partner was too low, she needed to improve the conditions of life for her two school-aged children. Today the needs of this humble mother is the acquisition of primary material to make the baked goods. For this reason she is asking Ceprodel to be the beneficiary of credits to continue her humble business. She has a record of 12 credits with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Conover, Kiva.org volunteer.

La elaboración de pan, picos, manjares, galletas y empanadas es el negocio que se dedica la seora Eudoxia O. teniendo su propia panadería en las afueras del mercado la Terminal del departamento de León.

Se dedica a este negocio desde hace15 años debido a que los ingresos de su compañero de vida eran suficientemente bajos y por tal razón necesitaba mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus dos hijas en edad escolar. Hoy en día la necesidad que atraviesa esta humilde madre es la adquisición de la materia prima para elaborar los productos de la panadería. Por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos para continuar con su humilde negocio. Su record es de 12 créditos con Ceprodel.

loans.use: Bakery

loans.name: Hernawati

texts.en: Hernawati, 31, is the mother of 1 child. To support her family, she sells spices such as garlic, walnut, etc. She puts those spices into plastic bags then sells them at the market or shops nearby, earning $5 a day. She also sells clothes on credit door-to-door and earns another $10 a week. She is a member of MBK and requesting a loan of $100 to add to her business capital. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to business capital

loans.name: Kari Marina

texts.es:
For four years, in the Estacion market in the city of Leon, Ms. Kari S. has worked selling products for the home and food in her general store. Due to being a single mother of two children that she has to provide with an education, she has been a very strong and hard working woman that has invested in her business in order to improve her economic situation, which according to her has been very hard due to the fact that she is the only one providing for the home.

Before having this business she was a house wife but when her children were born she sought a way to improve her economic situation and today, through the credits that she received from Ceprodel (14 credits), she has been able to acquire larger volumes of her products. She has also been able to buy a display case to hold her products and to pay more attention to her clients. Her current necessity is to buy more products again.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Conover, Kiva.org volunteer. Desde hace cuatro años, en el mercado la Estación en la ciudad de León, la señora Kari S. se dedica a la venta de productos del hogar y comestibles siendo su negocio una pulpería. Por ser madre soltera de 2 hijos a los que tiene que brindarles educación, ha sido una dama muy esforzada y trabajadora la cual ha invertido en su negocio para el mejoramiento de su situación económica la cual según cuenta ha estado muy difícil por el hecho de que ella es el único sostén en el hogar.

Antes de tener este negocio se dedicaba al trabajo de ama de casa pero al nacer sus pequeños busca la manera de cómo mejorar su situación económica y hoy en día, por medio de Créditos realizados en Ceprodel (14 créditos) ha realizado mayores volúmenes de compra de sus productos. Además ha logrado comprar una vitrina para colocar sus productos y brindar una mejor atención a sus clientes. Su necesidad actual es la compra de los productos una vez mas.

loans.use: To provide more products for a business

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Thúy, 37 years old, lives with her husband and two school age children. When a branch of the TYM Fund was first opened in Sóc Sơn, she joined for one year and then left due to all her time was spent for two young children. In 2000, she rejoined the Fund and borrowed money to open a general store. Her house, on the Route 131, is an ideal location for the business. Most of her customers are farmers from nearby rural areas. The family’s economy is getting better, monthly income is 300USD. She is applying for a loan of 1200USD to replenish her store getting ready for up coming Tết.

From Wikipedia: Tết Nguyên Đán, more commonly known by its shortened name Tết, is the most important and popular holiday and festival in Vietnam. It is the Vietnamese New Year which is based on the Chinese calendar, a lunisolar calendar. The name Tết Nguyên Đán is Sino-Vietnamese for Feast of the First Morning, derived from the Hán nôm characters 節元旦. In modern Chinese, the characters for Nguyên Ðán (元旦) have evolved to refer to New Year in the Gregorian calendar, that is, January 1.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Phạm Thị Thúy, 37 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 2 con đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Thời gian Quỹ Tình thương mới về hoạt động trên địa bàn huyện Sóc Sơn, chị đã tham gia được 1 năm, song vì điều kiện con nhỏ, không có thời gian đi sinh hoạt nên chị đã xin ra khỏi Quỹ. Với bản tính năng động không chịu mãi cảnh nghèo, chị rất muốn vay vốn nhưng không biết vay ở đâu. Năm 2000 chị lai tiếp tục xin quay lại Quỹ và mở của hàng kinh doanh tạp hóa tại trục đường 131 là nơi rất thuận tiên cho việc buôn bán. Khách hàng của chị là ở phần lớn ở các vùng nông thôn đến lấy buôn. Cuộc sống gia đình chị Thúy đã có nhiều chuyển biến, mức thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình là 300USD/tháng. Chị vừa làm đơn xin vay 1200USD để mua hàng phục vụ Tết.

loans.use: Buy beer, cakes, candy for her grocery store

loans.name: Iin

texts.en: Iin, 27, is the mother of 3 children ages10, 7 and 1. She sells kitchen wares such as glassess, plates, rice cookers, etc. on credit door-to-door around the villages, earning $10 a week. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $100 to add to her inventory .  She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her inventory

loans.name: César Antonio

texts.es:
Mr. Cesar S. lives in the Sabana Grande region, which is an area populated by very needy families. Mr. S. is married and has a 3 year old daughter. Along with his wife, he has a business selling prepared food at night.

Previously they worked in a stand at a market selling brand new clothes. Later on they decided to take a chance and try the business of the "Fritanga". A Fritanga is a street side food stand that sells inexpensive meals to passersby. They rented the stand they had at the market to a family member.

They are doing very well in this new business. They have been able to get ahead and are expanding constantly. They need the loan to purchase a new stove to cook their roasts and to buy foodstuffs to prepare their meals. They hope that the loan will help them attract more customers.

Translated from the Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Don César habita en la comarca Sabana Grande, un lugar con muchas necesidades para las familias que ahí residen. Don César es casado y tiene una pequeña hija de 3 años, junto a su esposa tiene un negocio de venta de fritangas por la noche.

Anteriormente trabajan en un tramo de una Mercado, vendiendo ropa nueva, pero decidieron aventurarse en el negocio de la Fritanga. El tramo que tenían en el mercado se lo alquilan a un familiar de ellos.

El negocio de la fritanga les ha salido muy bueno, han salido adelante y están creciendo constantemente. Necesitan el crédito para comprar una estufa para poner sus asados, y también para comprar alimentos para hacer sus comidas. Esperan poder atraer mayor cantidad de clientes al contar con mayor capital de trabajo.

loans.use: To purchase a stove and foodstuffs

loans.name: Titi

texts.en: Titi, 41, is the mother of 4 children. She makes flavoured ice by putting them into small plastic bags then freezing them before selling them. She earns an irregular income from this business, but sometimes she could earn $4 a day.  Her husband, E., sells vegetables and earns $10 a day. She is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan of $100 to expand her business. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Hindun

texts.en: Hindun, 36, sells fried snacks and ice door-to-door around the villages earning $5 a day. Her husband, A., is a coolie who earns an irregular income. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $75 to expand her business. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Sulastri

texts.en: Sulastri is 21 and doesn't have any children.  She and her husband I. have a small shop infront of their house where they sell vegetables, groceries, etc. They could earn $15 a day with a small profit. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $75 to add her inventory. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her inventory

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trần Thị T., 50 years old, joins the TYM Fund in 1997. She used her first loan to invest in animal husbandry and scrap material. The family’s economy is getting better and she is able to support her only child’s education who is now in college. In 2002, she engaged in restaurant business. It all has been well. The monthly income is 150USD. She would like to take out a loan of 400USD to recondition the farm and buy more piglets. She lives with her husband and her child in Ý Yên, Nam Định.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Trần Thị T., 50 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 1997. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi kết hợp với việc đi thu mua phế liệu ở các nơi về bán để trả tiền tuần. Kinh tế gia đình qua các năm đã được thay đổi. Chị đã đủ điều kiện nuôi người con duy nhất ăn học trưởng thành. Hiện nay cháu đang học đại học. Từ năm 2002, chị T. chuyển sang kinh doanh hàng ăn. Công việc thuận lợi, thu nhập mỗi tháng đạt mức 150USD. Chị muốn tiếp tục vay 400USD về sửa sang chuồng trại và mua giống lợn gà. Chị T. đang sống cùng chồng và con tại Ý Yên, Nam Định.

loans.use: Buy pigs, chickens

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Hát, 36 years old, lives in Ý Yên, joined the TYM Fund in 2004 at the time her family’s economy was in hardship. She took out loans to invest in animal husbandry and the income from tH. improved the situation somewH.. She and her husband have 3 small children so they work hard. Her husband, Chức, is working as a carpenter away from home, in Nghệ An. She would like to take out a loan of 1200USD fron the Fund. 400USD of the funds will be used to recondition the farm and buy more piglets; the remain 800USD is to purchase a table saw for her husband. The family monthly income is 300USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Phạm Thị Hát, 36 tuổi, sống tại Ý Yên, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2004 trong điều kiện gia đình kinh tế còn khó khăn. Sau khi vay vốn từ Quỹ Tình thương về phát triển chăn nuôi kinh tế gia đình đã phần nào được nâng lên. Chị có 3 cháu nhỏ nên 2 vợ chồng phải tích cực làm việc tạo thu nhập. Hiện nay anh Chức, chồng chị, đi làm nghề mộc ở Nghệ An còn chị ở nhà chăn nuôi và nuôi dạy con. Chị muốn vay 1200USD trong đó 400USD dùng để sửa sang chuồng trại và mua lợn giống còn 800USD để chồng mua máy cưa mang vào Nghệ An làm nghề. Thu nhập của gia đình hiện tại là 300USD/tháng

loans.use: Buy saw machine, pigs

loans.name: Yakaar 1 Group

texts.fr:
We are a group of young men who are trading cereals. We go and buy them once a week at the weekly markets organized in the neighboring villages. We then resale them after transformation. This is how we got started with a first loan that we have repaid completely. Now the group has grown and has a lot more members, most of them women. We have regrouped them in an association that will do the same thing as us.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Nous sommes un groupe de jeunes hommes qui fait du commerce de céréales que nous allons acheter dans les foires hebdomadairesqui sont organisées dans les villages limitrophes et que nous venons revendre après transformation pour le revaloriser. C'est ainsi que nous avons débuté avec un premier prêt que nous avons fini de rermbourser et maintenant, le groupe s'est agrandi avec beaucoup plus de membres dont la plupart sont des femmes que nous avons regroupé dans une association qui va faire la même chose que nous.

loans.use: Purchase of cereals for transformation and resale

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Hường, 50 years old, lives with her husband and two children in Ý Yên, Nam Định. She joins the TYM Fund in 1999. In the first few years she borrowed money to invest an animal husbandry, her husband, Dũng, worked as a general laborer to pay the loan weekly. After awhile she started a grocery store. The income from the store is used for the repayments so her husband now can stay home farming and helping in her store. Few years later, the family’s economy is getting better. All children are grown up. She would like to apply for a loan of 1200USD to replenish her store getting ready for Tết.

From Wikipedia: Tết Nguyên Đán, more commonly known by its shortened name Tết, is the most important and popular holiday and festival in Vietnam. It is the Vietnamese New Year which is based on the Chinese calendar, a lunisolar calendar. The name Tết Nguyên Đán is Sino-Vietnamese for Feast of the First Morning, derived from the Hán nôm characters 節元旦. In modern Chinese, the characters for Nguyên Ðán (元旦) have evolved to refer to New Year in the Gregorian calendar, that is, January 1.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Phạm Thị Hường, 50 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại Ý Yên, Nam Định. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 1999. Những năm đầu tham gia chị vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn còn chồng đi làm thuê để lấy tiền trả tiền tuần. Sau một thời gian chị chuyển sang kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa. Công việc này mang lại thu nhập từng ngày giúp chị có thể hoàn trả tiền tuần. Anh Dũng chồng chị không phải đi làm thuê nữa mà ở nhà làm việc đồng áng và giúp vợ trông nom cửa hàng. Qua các năm kinh tế gia đình chị đã dần dần nâng lên, đến nay các con chị đều đã trưởng thành. Chị Hường đang đề nghị vay 1200USD để lấy hàng bán phục vụ Tết cho nhân dân trong vùng và mua phông bạt bát đĩa phục vụ các đám hiếu, hỉ trong vùng

loans.use: Buy canvas, bowls, plates for hire

loans.name: Truong Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Truong Thi Y., 36 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva's partner) since 2003. Her husband is a disabled veteran (He lost one arm). Mrs. Y. is pretty much the sole bread winner in the family. Her two children are still small, making her life even harder. She always try to best use her loans. She has used the loan to buy sundry goods to wholesale. Her family income has improved significantly over time. She is able to furnish her house with a television and a refrigerator. Mrs. Y. is applying for another loan of 400 USD to buy more sundry goods.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong NguY., Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trương Thị Yến, 36 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2003. Chồng là thương binh mất một cánh tay, công việc kinh tế gia đình chủ yếu trông vào chị. Hai con còn nhỏ, hoàn cảnh khó khăn, chị Yến luôn tìm mọi cách để sử dụng đồng vốn vay có hiệu quả. Qua các năm vay vốn chị dùng tiền vay về lấy hàng tạp phẩm về bán buôn cho các hộ gia đình bán lẻ. Đến nay gia đình kinh tế đã dần dần nâng lên, chị đã sắm được các vật dụng như tivi, tủ lạnh ... Chị đang làm hồ sơ vay thêm vốn về để đi lấy hàng về bán. Mức xin vay của chị Yến là 400USD

loans.use: Buy sundry goods to wholesale

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is a twenty nine year old single mother with two children ages three and six.  For ten years, Juana has sold clothes and music in the San Lorenzo market.  The business was inherited from her mother who became too old to work.  Thanks to Juana’s dedication and hard work she has been able to save enough money to finish constructing a house for her and her daughters.  She is also earning enough income to pay for her daughter to attend school.  

With this loan, Juana will purchase more clothes and music to sell.  In the future she wants to buy her own store to sell all types of merchandise and hopes that with an increase in business she will be able to employ others as well.

loans.use: To buy music disks and clothes.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Pham Thi N., 41 years old, lives with her husband and her three children (who are still in school) in Y Yen. She joined TYM Fund (Kiva's partner) since 2005. Her husband casts copper while she collects and sells wasted products. During the past two years, Mrs. N. uses most of her loan to buy these wasted products and then to sell them to the wholesalers. The job is hard, but it doesn't bring her much income. Mrs. N. wants to borrow 575 USD so that her husband can buy a specialized machine to process copper. N. hopes their income will increase after buying this machine. Right now her family monthly income is 150 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị N., 41 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 3 con đang trong độ tuổi đi học tại Ý Yên. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2005. Chồng chị đi làm nghề đúc đồng còn chị đi thu mua phế liệu. Trong 2 năm qua, những đồng vốn vay từ Quỹ được chị N. sử dụng chủ yếu cho việc thu mua phế liệu ở các nơi về bán cho các đại lý thu mua trong vùng. Công việc thu mua vất vả nhưng thu nhập mang lại cũng bình thường. Hiện nay chị N. đang muốn vay 575USD để chồng chị mua máy gia công hàng đúc để nhận các hàng đúc đồng về làm không phải đi làm thuê. Chị hy vọng thu nhập sẽ tăng lên sau khi mua được máy. Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình là 150USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy specialized machine to process copper

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Pham Thi L., 50 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva's partner) since 2007. She lives with her husband and two children in Lam town, Nam Dinh province. Her province is famous for casting copper. Before L., there have been a lot of women borrowing money to buy and sell copper. However, L. is still afraid of not being able to pay the weekly repayment. Until recently (2007), she decided to borrow 200USD. She uses that loan to buy and then cast copper. Her income is 8 to 10 USD per day. Her business is doing quite well, and this time Mrs. L. would like to borrow 575 USD to buy more materials, to increase her income and bring jobs for her two children.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị L., 50 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2007. Chị sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại thị trấn Lâm, Nam Định. Ở một làng nghề truyền thống đúc đồng, trước chị L. đã có rất nhiều chị em vay vốn về kinh doanh mặt hàng này. Nhưng chị vẫn ngại về cách hoàn trả hàng tuần. Đến năm ngoái chị mới quyết định xin vay 200USD. Trong năm đầu chị đầu tư mua đồng về đúc mỗi ngày cho thu nhập từ 8-10USD. Thấy công việc tiến triển thuận lợi, sang năm thứ 2 này chị Lam mạnh dạn vay thêm 575USD về để mua được nhiều nguyên liệu hơn, tăng thu nhập và tạo công ăn việc làm cho 2 con.

loans.use: Buy copper to cast

loans.name: Oñndivepa Group

texts.en:
This committee of 15 women call themselves “Oñondivepa” and work together to support their growing independent businesses. They have united in their effort to grow their businesses and their profits. They have taken out a previous loan together and promptly paid it back with Fundación Paraguaya.

Some of them are the sole providers for their children and are relying on the help of a loan to help them purchase necessary products to keep their investments lucrative. This loan will be used to purchase fruits, vegetables, cosmetics, hair products, fabrics, and other food production goods.

loans.use: To buy various things for their businesses including: fruits, vegetable, baking goods, refreshments, and beauty and hair products.

loans.name: Raquel Mercedes

texts.es:
Mrs. N.'s business is food sales. She prepares the food in her home very early in the morning, and then later sells it in the market. To be able to run her business, she buys ingredients on loan, paying for them each week - and when she has the opportunity, she immediately makes her purchase.

Mrs. N. has had her business for two years and started with a loan of $2,000 cordobas that she obtained from a moneylender.

Ceprodel has granted her with 4 loans over the past 1 1/2 years. These loans have had a big impact on her business. The demand for her food has grown and the loans have allowed her to purchase ingredients and at the same time, have allowed her to purchase a stand in the "food court" section of the Santa Ana market in Chinandega.
